723 /** Compare two protocol requests
724  *
725  * Allows protocol requests to be prioritised with a function
726  * specified by the API client. Defaults to by pointer address
727  * if no function is specified.
728  *
729  * @param[in] a treq to compare to b.
730  * @param[in] b treq to compare to a.
731  * @return
732  * - +1 if a > b.
733  * - 0 if a == b.
734  * - -1 if a < b.
735  */
736 static int8_t _trunk_request_prioritise(void const *a, void const *b)
737 {
738  fr_trunk_request_t const *treq_a = talloc_get_type_abort_const(a, fr_trunk_request_t);
739  fr_trunk_request_t const *treq_b = talloc_get_type_abort_const(b, fr_trunk_request_t);
740 
741  fr_assert(treq_a->pub.trunk == treq_b->pub.trunk);
742 
743  return treq_a->pub.trunk->funcs.request_prioritise(treq_a->pub.preq, treq_b->pub.preq);
744 }
745 
746 /** Remove a request from all connection lists
747  *
748  * A common function used by init, fail, complete state functions to disassociate
749  * a request from a connection in preparation for freeing or reassignment.
750  *
751  * Despite its unassuming name, this function is *the* place to put calls to
752  * functions which need to be called when the number of requests associated with
753  * a connection changes.
754  *
755  * Trunk requests will always be passed to this function before they're removed
756  * from a connection, even if the requests are being freed.
757  *
758  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
759  */
760 static void trunk_request_remove_from_conn(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
761 {
762  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
763  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
764 
765  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
766 
767  switch (treq->pub.state) {
768  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
769  return; /* Not associated with connection */
770 
771  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
772  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PENDING(treq);
773  break;
774 
775  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
776  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PARTIAL(treq);
777  break;
778 
779  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
780  REQUEST_EXTRACT_SENT(treq);
781  break;
782 
783  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
784  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL(treq);
785  break;
786 
787  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL:
788  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL_PARTIAL(treq);
789  break;
790 
791  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT:
792  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL_SENT(treq);
793  break;
794 
795  default:
796  fr_assert(0);
797  break;
798  }
799 
800  DEBUG3("[%" PRIu64 "] Trunk connection released request %" PRIu64, tconn->pub.conn->id, treq->id);
801 
802  /*
803  * Release any connection specific resources the
804  * treq holds.
805  */
806  DO_REQUEST_CONN_RELEASE(treq);
807 
808  switch (tconn->pub.state){
809  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
810  trunk_connection_auto_unfull(tconn); /* Check if we can switch back to active */
811  if (tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL) break; /* Only fallthrough if conn is now active */
812  FALL_THROUGH;
813 
814  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
815  CONN_REORDER(tconn);
816  break;
817 
818  default:
819  break;
820  }
821 
822  treq->pub.tconn = NULL;
823 
824  /*
825  * Request removed from the connection
826  * see if we need up deregister I/O events.
827  */
828  trunk_connection_event_update(tconn);
829 }
830 
831 /** Transition a request to the unassigned state, in preparation for re-assignment
832  *
833  * @note treq->tconn may be inviable after calling
834  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause are not used.
835  * This is due to call to trunk_request_remove_from_conn.
836  *
837  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
838  */
839 static void trunk_request_enter_unassigned(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
840 {
841  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
842 
843  switch (treq->pub.state) {
844  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
845  return;
846 
847  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG:
848  REQUEST_EXTRACT_BACKLOG(treq);
849  break;
850 
851  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
852  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
853  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL:
854  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT:
855  trunk_request_remove_from_conn(treq);
856  break;
857 
858  default:
859  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED);
860  }
861 
862  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED);
863 }
864 
865 /** Transition a request to the backlog state, adding it to the backlog of the trunk
866  *
867  * @note treq->tconn and treq may be inviable after calling
868  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause are not used.
869  * This is due to call to trunk_manage.
870  *
871  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
872  * @param[in] new Whether this is a new request.
873  */
874 static void trunk_request_enter_backlog(fr_trunk_request_t *treq, bool new)
875 {
876  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
877  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;;
878 
879  switch (treq->pub.state) {
880  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT:
881  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
882  break;
883 
884  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
885  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PENDING(treq);
886  break;
887 
888  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
889  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL(treq);
890  break;
891 
892  default:
893  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG);
894  }
895 
896  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG);
897  fr_heap_insert(trunk->backlog, treq); /* Insert into the backlog heap */
898 
899  /*
900  * A new request has entered the trunk.
901  * Re-calculate request/connection ratios.
902  */
903  if (new) trunk_requests_per_connection(NULL, NULL, trunk, fr_time(), false);
904 
905  /*
906  * To reduce latency, if there's no connections
907  * in the connecting state, call the trunk manage
908  * function immediately.
909  *
910  * Likewise, if there's draining connections
911  * which could be moved back to active call
912  * the trunk manage function.
913  *
914  * Remember requests only enter the backlog if
915  * there's no connections which can service them.
916  */
917  if ((fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(treq->pub.trunk, FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING) == 0) ||
918  (fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(treq->pub.trunk, FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING) > 0)) {
919  fr_trunk_connection_manage_schedule(treq->pub.trunk);
920  }
921 }
922 
923 /** Transition a request to the pending state, adding it to the backlog of an active connection
924  *
925  * All trunk requests being added to a connection get passed to this function.
926  * All trunk requests being removed from a connection get passed to #trunk_request_remove_from_conn.
927  *
928  * @note treq->tconn and treq may be inviable after calling
929  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause is not used.
930  * This is due to call to trunk_connection_event_update.
931  *
932  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
933  * @param[in] tconn to enqueue the request on.
934  * @param[in] new Whether this is a new request.
935  */
936 static void trunk_request_enter_pending(fr_trunk_request_t *treq, fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn, bool new)
937 {
938  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
939 
940  fr_assert(tconn->pub.trunk == trunk);
941  fr_assert(IS_SERVICEABLE(tconn));
942 
943  switch (treq->pub.state) {
944  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT:
945  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
946  fr_assert(!treq->pub.tconn);
947  break;
948 
949  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG:
950  fr_assert(!treq->pub.tconn);
951  REQUEST_EXTRACT_BACKLOG(treq);
952  break;
953 
954  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL: /* Moved from another connection */
955  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL(treq);
956  break;
957 
958  default:
959  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING);
960  }
961 
962  /*
963  * Assign the new connection first this first so
964  * it appears in the state log.
965  */
966  treq->pub.tconn = tconn;
967 
968  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING);
969  DEBUG3("[%" PRIu64 "] Trunk connection assigned request %"PRIu64, tconn->pub.conn->id, treq->id);
970  fr_heap_insert(tconn->pending, treq);
971 
972  /*
973  * A new request has entered the trunk.
974  * Re-calculate request/connection ratios.
975  */
976  if (new) trunk_requests_per_connection(NULL, NULL, trunk, fr_time(), false);
977 
978  /*
979  * Check if we need to automatically transition the
980  * connection to full.
981  */
982  trunk_connection_auto_full(tconn);
983 
984  /*
985  * Reorder the connection in the heap now it has an
986  * additional request.
987  */
988  if (tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) CONN_REORDER(tconn);
989 
990  /*
991  * We have a new request, see if we need to register
992  * for I/O events.
993  */
994  trunk_connection_event_update(tconn);
995 }
996 
997 /** Transition a request to the partial state, indicating that is has been partially sent
998  *
999  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
1000  */
1001 static void trunk_request_enter_partial(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1002 {
1003  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1004  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1005 
1006  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1007 
1008  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1009  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING: /* All requests go through pending, even requeued ones */
1010  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PENDING(treq);
1011  break;
1012 
1013  default:
1014  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL);
1015  }
1016 
1017  fr_assert(!tconn->partial);
1018  tconn->partial = treq;
1019 
1020  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL);
1021 }
1022 
1023 /** Transition a request to the sent state, indicating that it's been sent in its entirety
1024  *
1025  * @note treq->tconn and treq may be inviable after calling
1026  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause is not used.
1027  * This is due to call to trunk_connection_event_update.
1028  *
1029  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
1030  */
1031 static void trunk_request_enter_sent(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1032 {
1033  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1034  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1035 
1036  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1037 
1038  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1039  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
1040  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PENDING(treq);
1041  break;
1042 
1043  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
1044  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PARTIAL(treq);
1045  break;
1046 
1047  default:
1048  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT);
1049  }
1050 
1051  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT);
1052  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&tconn->sent, treq);
1053 
1054  /*
1055  * Update the connection's sent stats
1056  */
1057  tconn->sent_count++;
1058 
1059  /*
1060  * Enforces max_uses
1061  */
1062  if ((trunk->conf.max_uses > 0) && (tconn->sent_count >= trunk->conf.max_uses)) {
1063  trunk_connection_enter_draining_to_free(tconn);
1064  }
1065 
1066  /*
1067  * We just sent a request, we probably need
1068  * to tell the event loop we want to be
1069  * notified if there's data available.
1070  */
1071  trunk_connection_event_update(tconn);
1072 }
1073 
1074 /** Transition a request to the cancel state, placing it in a connection's cancellation list
1075  *
1076  * If a request_cancel_send callback is provided, that callback will
1077  * be called periodically for requests which were cancelled due to
1078  * a signal.
1079  *
1080  * The request_cancel_send callback will dequeue cancelled requests
1081  * and inform a remote server that the result is no longer required.
1082  *
1083  * A request must enter this state before being added to the backlog
1084  * of another connection if it's been sent or partially sent.
1085  *
1086  * @note treq->tconn and treq may be inviable after calling
1087  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause is not used.
1088  * This is due to call to trunk_connection_event_update.
1089  *
1090  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
1091  * @param[in] reason Why the request was cancelled.
1092  * Should be one of:
1093  * - FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_SIGNAL request cancelled
1094  * because of a signal from the interpreter.
1095  * - FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_MOVE request cancelled
1096  * because the connection failed and it needs
1097  * to be assigned to a new connection.
1098  * - FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_REQUEUE request cancelled
1099  * as it needs to be resent on the same connection.
1100  */
1101 static void trunk_request_enter_cancel(fr_trunk_request_t *treq, fr_trunk_cancel_reason_t reason)
1102 {
1103  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1104  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1105 
1106  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1107 
1108  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1109  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
1110  REQUEST_EXTRACT_PARTIAL(treq);
1111  break;
1112 
1113  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
1114  REQUEST_EXTRACT_SENT(treq);
1115  break;
1116 
1117  default:
1118  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL);
1119  }
1120 
1121  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL);
1122  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&tconn->cancel, treq);
1123  treq->cancel_reason = reason;
1124 
1125  DO_REQUEST_CANCEL(treq, reason);
1126 
1127  /*
1128  * Our treq is no longer bound to an actual
1129  * request_t *, as we can't guarantee the
1130  * lifetime of the original request_t *.
1131  */
1132  if (treq->cancel_reason == FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_SIGNAL) treq->pub.request = NULL;
1133 
1134  /*
1135  * Register for I/O write events if we need to.
1136  */
1137  trunk_connection_event_update(treq->pub.tconn);
1138 }
1139 
1140 /** Transition a request to the cancel_partial state, placing it in a connection's cancel_partial slot
1141  *
1142  * The request_demux function is then responsible for signalling
1143  * that the cancel request is complete when the remote server
1144  * acknowledges the cancellation request.
1145  *
1146  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
1147  */
1148 static void trunk_request_enter_cancel_partial(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1149 {
1150  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1151  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1152 
1153  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1154  fr_assert(trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux);
1155  fr_assert(treq->cancel_reason == FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_SIGNAL);
1156 
1157  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1158  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL: /* The only valid state cancel_sent can be reached from */
1159  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL(treq);
1160  break;
1161 
1162  default:
1163  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL);
1164  }
1165 
1166  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL);
1167  fr_assert(!tconn->partial);
1168  tconn->cancel_partial = treq;
1169 }
1170 
1171 /** Transition a request to the cancel_sent state, placing it in a connection's cancel_sent list
1172  *
1173  * The request_demux function is then responsible for signalling
1174  * that the cancel request is complete when the remote server
1175  * acknowledges the cancellation request.
1176  *
1177  * @note treq->tconn and treq may be inviable after calling
1178  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause is not used.
1179  * This is due to call to trunk_connection_event_update.
1180  *
1181  * @param[in] treq to trigger a state change for.
1182  */
1183 static void trunk_request_enter_cancel_sent(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1184 {
1185  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1186  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1187 
1188  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1189  fr_assert(trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux);
1190  fr_assert(treq->cancel_reason == FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_SIGNAL);
1191 
1192  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1193  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL:
1194  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL_PARTIAL(treq);
1195  break;
1196 
1197  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
1198  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL(treq);
1199  break;
1200 
1201  default:
1202  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT);
1203  }
1204 
1205  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT);
1206  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&tconn->cancel_sent, treq);
1207 
1208  /*
1209  * De-register for I/O write events
1210  * and register the read events
1211  * to drain the cancel ACKs.
1212  */
1213  trunk_connection_event_update(treq->pub.tconn);
1214 }
1215 
1216 /** Cancellation was acked, the request is complete, free it
1217  *
1218  * The API client will not be informed, as the original request_t *
1219  * will likely have been freed by this point.
1220  *
1221  * @note treq will be inviable after a call to this function.
1222  * treq->tconn may be inviable after calling
1223  * if treq->conn and fr_connection_signals_pause is not used.
1224  * This is due to call to trunk_request_remove_from_conn.
1225  *
1226  * @param[in] treq to mark as complete.
1227  */
1228 static void trunk_request_enter_cancel_complete(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1229 {
1230  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1231  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1232 
1233  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1234  if (!fr_cond_assert(!treq->pub.request)) return; /* Only a valid state for request_t * which have been cancelled */
1235 
1236  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1237  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT:
1238  REQUEST_EXTRACT_CANCEL_SENT(treq);
1239  break;
1240 
1241  default:
1242  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_COMPLETE);
1243  }
1244 
1245  trunk_request_remove_from_conn(treq);
1246 
1247  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_COMPLETE);
1248  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq); /* Free the request */
1249 }
1250 
1251 /** Request completed successfully, inform the API client and free the request
1252  *
1253  * @note treq will be inviable after a call to this function.
1254  * treq->tconn may also be inviable due to call to
1255  * trunk_request_remove_from_conn.
1256  *
1257  * @param[in] treq to mark as complete.
1258  */
1259 static void trunk_request_enter_complete(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1260 {
1261  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1262  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1263 
1264  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1265 
1266  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1267  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
1268  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
1269  trunk_request_remove_from_conn(treq);
1270  break;
1271 
1272  default:
1273  REQUEST_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_COMPLETE);
1274  }
1275 
1276  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_COMPLETE);
1277  DO_REQUEST_COMPLETE(treq);
1278  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq); /* Free the request */
1279 }
1280 
1281 /** Request failed, inform the API client and free the request
1282  *
1283  * @note treq will be inviable after a call to this function.
1284  * treq->tconn may also be inviable due to call to
1285  * trunk_request_remove_from_conn.
1286  *
1287  * @param[in] treq to mark as failed.
1288  */
1289 static void trunk_request_enter_failed(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1290 {
1291  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1292  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1293  fr_trunk_request_state_t prev = treq->pub.state;
1294 
1295  if (!fr_cond_assert(!tconn || (tconn->pub.trunk == trunk))) return;
1296 
1297  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1298  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG:
1299  REQUEST_EXTRACT_BACKLOG(treq);
1300  break;
1301 
1302  default:
1303  trunk_request_remove_from_conn(treq);
1304  break;
1305  }
1306 
1307  REQUEST_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_FAILED);
1308  DO_REQUEST_FAIL(treq, prev);
1309  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq); /* Free the request */
1310 }
1311 
1312 /** Check to see if a trunk request can be enqueued
1313  *
1314  * @param[out] tconn_out Connection the request may be enqueued on.
1315  * @param[in] trunk To enqueue requests on.
1316  * @param[in] request associated with the treq (if any).
1317  * @return
1318  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK caller should enqueue request on provided tconn.
1319  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG Request should be queued in the backlog.
1320  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY Unable to enqueue request as we have no spare
1321  * connections or backlog space.
1322  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE Can't enqueue because the destination is
1323  * unreachable.
1324  */
1325 static fr_trunk_enqueue_t trunk_request_check_enqueue(fr_trunk_connection_t **tconn_out, fr_trunk_t *trunk,
1326  request_t *request)
1327 {
1328  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn;
1329  /*
1330  * If we have an active connection then
1331  * return that.
1332  */
1333  tconn = fr_heap_peek(trunk->active);
1334  if (tconn) {
1335  *tconn_out = tconn;
1336  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK;
1337  }
1338 
1339  /*
1340  * Unlike the connection pool, we don't need
1341  * to drive any internal processes by feeding
1342  * it requests.
1343  *
1344  * If the last event to occur was a failure
1345  * we refuse to enqueue new requests until
1346  * one or more connections comes online.
1347  */
1348  if (!trunk->conf.backlog_on_failed_conn &&
1349  trunk->pub.last_failed && (trunk->pub.last_connected < trunk->pub.last_failed)) {
1350  RATE_LIMIT_LOCAL_ROPTIONAL(&trunk->limit_last_failure_log,
1351  RWARN, WARN, "Refusing to enqueue requests - "
1352  "No active connections and last event was a connection failure");
1353 
1354  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE;
1355  }
1356 
1357 
1358  /*
1359  * Only enforce if we're limiting maximum
1360  * number of connections, and maximum
1361  * number of requests per connection.
1362  *
1363  * The alloc function also checks this
1364  * which is why this is only done for
1365  * debug builds.
1366  */
1367  if (trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn && trunk->conf.max) {
1368  uint64_t limit;
1369 
1370  limit = trunk->conf.max * (uint64_t)trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn;
1371  if (limit > 0) {
1372  uint64_t total_reqs;
1373 
1374  total_reqs = fr_trunk_request_count_by_state(trunk, FR_TRUNK_CONN_ALL,
1375  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL);
1376  if (total_reqs >= limit) {
1377  RATE_LIMIT_LOCAL_ROPTIONAL(&trunk->limit_max_requests_alloc_log,
1378  RWARN, WARN, "Refusing to alloc requests - "
1379  "Limit of %"PRIu64" (max = %u * per_connection_max = %u) "
1380  "requests reached",
1381  limit, trunk->conf.max, trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn);
1382  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY;
1383  }
1384  }
1385  }
1386 
1387  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG;
1388 }
1389 
1390 /** Enqueue a request which has never been assigned to a connection or was previously cancelled
1391  *
1392  * @param[in] treq to re enqueue. Must have been removed
1393  * from its existing connection with
1394  * #trunk_connection_requests_dequeue.
1395  * @return
1396  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK Request was re-enqueued.
1397  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY Request enqueueing failed because we're at capacity.
1398  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE Enqueuing failed for some reason.
1399  * Usually because the connection to the resource is down.
1400  */
1401 static fr_trunk_enqueue_t trunk_request_enqueue_existing(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1402 {
1403  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1404  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = NULL;
1405  fr_trunk_enqueue_t ret;
1406 
1407  /*
1408  * Must *NOT* still be assigned to another connection
1409  */
1410  fr_assert(!treq->pub.tconn);
1411 
1412  ret = trunk_request_check_enqueue(&tconn, trunk, treq->pub.request);
1413  switch (ret) {
1414  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK:
1415  if (trunk->conf.always_writable) {
1416  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
1417  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, false);
1418  trunk_connection_writable(tconn);
1419  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1420  } else {
1421  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, false);
1422  }
1423  break;
1424 
1425  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG:
1426  /*
1427  * No more connections and request
1428  * is already in the backlog.
1429  *
1430  * Signal our caller it should stop
1431  * trying to drain the backlog.
1432  */
1433  if (treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY;
1434  trunk_request_enter_backlog(treq, false);
1435  break;
1436 
1437  default:
1438  break;
1439  }
1440 
1441  return ret;
1442 }
1443 
1444 /** Shift requests in the specified states onto new connections
1445  *
1446  * This function will blindly dequeue any requests in the specified state and get
1447  * them back to the unassigned state, cancelling any sent or partially sent requests.
1448  *
1449  * This function does not check that dequeuing a request in a particular state is a
1450  * sane or sensible thing to do, that's up to the caller!
1451  *
1452  * @param[out] out A list to insert the newly dequeued and unassigned
1453  * requests into.
1454  * @param[in] tconn to dequeue requests from.
1455  * @param[in] states Dequeue request in these states.
1456  * @param[in] max The maximum number of requests to dequeue. 0 for unlimited.
1457  */
1458 static uint64_t trunk_connection_requests_dequeue(fr_dlist_head_t *out, fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn,
1459  int states, uint64_t max)
1460 {
1461  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
1462  uint64_t count = 0;
1463 
1464  if (max == 0) max = UINT64_MAX;
1465 
1466 #define OVER_MAX_CHECK if (++count > max) return (count - 1)
1467 
1468 #define DEQUEUE_ALL(_src_list, _state) \
1469  while ((treq = fr_dlist_head(_src_list))) { \
1470  OVER_MAX_CHECK; \
1471  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == (_state)); \
1472  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq); \
1473  fr_dlist_insert_tail(out, treq); \
1474  }
1475 
1476  /*
1477  * Don't need to do anything with
1478  * cancellation requests.
1479  */
1480  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL) DEQUEUE_ALL(&tconn->cancel,
1481  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL);
1482 
1483  /*
1484  * ...same with cancel inform
1485  */
1486  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT) DEQUEUE_ALL(&tconn->cancel_sent,
1487  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT);
1488 
1489  /*
1490  * ....same with cancel partial
1491  */
1492  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL) {
1493  OVER_MAX_CHECK;
1494  treq = tconn->cancel_partial;
1495  if (treq) {
1496  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL);
1497  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1498  fr_dlist_insert_tail(out, treq);
1499  }
1500  }
1501 
1502  /*
1503  * ...and pending.
1504  */
1505  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING) {
1506  while ((treq = fr_heap_peek(tconn->pending))) {
1507  OVER_MAX_CHECK;
1508  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING);
1509  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1510  fr_dlist_insert_tail(out, treq);
1511  }
1512  }
1513 
1514  /*
1515  * Cancel partially sent requests
1516  */
1517  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL) {
1518  OVER_MAX_CHECK;
1519  treq = tconn->partial;
1520  if (treq) {
1521  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL);
1522 
1523  /*
1524  * Don't allow the connection to change state whilst
1525  * we're draining requests from it.
1526  */
1527  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
1528  trunk_request_enter_cancel(treq, FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_MOVE);
1529  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1530  fr_dlist_insert_tail(out, treq);
1531  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1532  }
1533  }
1534 
1535  /*
1536  * Cancel sent requests
1537  */
1538  if (states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT) {
1539  /*
1540  * Don't allow the connection to change state whilst
1541  * we're draining requests from it.
1542  */
1543  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
1544  while ((treq = fr_dlist_head(&tconn->sent))) {
1545  OVER_MAX_CHECK;
1546  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT);
1547 
1548  trunk_request_enter_cancel(treq, FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_MOVE);
1549  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1550  fr_dlist_insert_tail(out, treq);
1551  }
1552  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1553  }
1554 
1555  return count;
1556 }
1557 
1558 /** Remove requests in specified states from a connection, attempting to distribute them to new connections
1559  *
1560  * @param[in] tconn To remove requests from.
1561  * @param[in] states One or more states or'd together.
1562  * @param[in] max The maximum number of requests to dequeue.
1563  * 0 for unlimited.
1564  * @param[in] fail_bound If true causes any requests bound to the connection to fail.
1565  * If false bound requests will not be moved.
1566  *
1567  * @return the number of requests re-queued.
1568  */
1569 static uint64_t trunk_connection_requests_requeue(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn, int states, uint64_t max,
1570  bool fail_bound)
1571 {
1572  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
1573  fr_dlist_head_t to_process;
1574  fr_trunk_request_t *treq = NULL;
1575  uint64_t moved = 0;
1576 
1577  if (max == 0) max = UINT64_MAX;
1578 
1579  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&to_process, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
1580 
1581  /*
1582  * Prevent the connection changing state whilst we're
1583  * working with it.
1584  *
1585  * There's a user callback that can be called by
1586  * trunk_request_enqueue_existing which can reconnect
1587  * the connection.
1588  */
1589  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
1590 
1591  /*
1592  * Remove non-cancelled requests from the connection
1593  */
1594  moved += trunk_connection_requests_dequeue(&to_process, tconn, states & ~FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_ALL, max);
1595 
1596  /*
1597  * Prevent requests being requeued on the same trunk
1598  * connection, which would break rebalancing.
1599  *
1600  * This is a bit of a hack, but nothing should test
1601  * for connection/list consistency in this code,
1602  * and if something is added later, it'll be flagged
1603  * by the tests.
1604  */
1605  if (tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) {
1606  int ret;
1607 
1608  ret = fr_heap_extract(trunk->active, tconn);
1609  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(ret == 0,
1610  "Failed extracting conn from active heap: %s", fr_strerror())) goto done;
1611 
1612  }
1613 
1614  /*
1615  * Loop over all the requests we gathered and
1616  * redistribute them to new connections.
1617  */
1618  while ((treq = fr_dlist_next(&to_process, treq))) {
1619  fr_trunk_request_t *prev;
1620 
1621  prev = fr_dlist_remove(&to_process, treq);
1622 
1623  /*
1624  * Attempts to re-queue a request
1625  * that's bound to a connection
1626  * results in a failure.
1627  */
1628  if (treq->bound_to_conn) {
1629  if (fail_bound || !IS_SERVICEABLE(tconn)) {
1630  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
1631  } else {
1632  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, false);
1633  }
1634  goto next;
1635  }
1636 
1637  switch (trunk_request_enqueue_existing(treq)) {
1638  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK:
1639  break;
1640 
1641  /*
1642  * A connection failed, and
1643  * there's no other connections
1644  * available to deal with the
1645  * load, it's been placed back
1646  * in the backlog.
1647  */
1648  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG:
1649  break;
1650 
1651  /*
1652  * If we fail to re-enqueue then
1653  * there's nothing to do except
1654  * fail the request.
1655  */
1656  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE:
1657  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY:
1658  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL:
1659  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
1660  break;
1661  }
1662  next:
1663  treq = prev;
1664  }
1665 
1666  /*
1667  * Add the connection back into the active list
1668  */
1669  if (tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) {
1670  int ret;
1671 
1672  ret = fr_heap_insert(trunk->active, tconn);
1673  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(ret == 0,
1674  "Failed re-inserting conn into active heap: %s", fr_strerror())) goto done;
1675  }
1676  if (moved >= max) goto done;
1677 
1678  /*
1679  * Deal with the cancelled requests specially we can't
1680  * queue them up again as they were only valid on that
1681  * specific connection.
1682  *
1683  * We just need to run them to completion which, as
1684  * they should already be in the unassigned state,
1685  * just means freeing them.
1686  */
1687  moved += trunk_connection_requests_dequeue(&to_process, tconn,
1688  states & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_ALL, max - moved);
1689  while ((treq = fr_dlist_next(&to_process, treq))) {
1690  fr_trunk_request_t *prev;
1691 
1692  prev = fr_dlist_remove(&to_process, treq);
1693  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq);
1694  treq = prev;
1695  }
1696 
1697 done:
1698 
1699  /*
1700  * Always re-calculate the request/connection
1701  * ratio at the end.
1702  *
1703  * This avoids having the state transition
1704  * functions do it.
1705  *
1706  * The ratio would be wrong when they calculated
1707  * it anyway, because a bunch of requests are
1708  * dequeued from the connection and temporarily
1709  * cease to exist from the perspective of the
1710  * trunk_requests_per_connection code.
1711  */
1712  trunk_requests_per_connection(NULL, NULL, trunk, fr_time(), false);
1713 
1714  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1715  return moved;
1716 }
1717 
1718 /** Move requests off of a connection and requeue elsewhere
1719  *
1720  * @note We don't re-queue on draining or draining to free, as requests should have already been
1721  * moved off of te connection. It's also dangerous as the trunk management code main
1722  * clean up a connection in this state when it's run on re-queue, and then the caller
1723  * may try and access a now freed connection.
1724  *
1725  * @param[in] tconn to move requests off of.
1726  * @param[in] states Only move requests in this state.
1727  * @param[in] max The maximum number of requests to dequeue. 0 for unlimited.
1728  * @param[in] fail_bound If true causes any requests bound to the connection to fail.
1729  * If false bound requests will not be moved.
1730  * @return The number of requests requeued.
1731  */
1732 uint64_t fr_trunk_connection_requests_requeue(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn, int states, uint64_t max, bool fail_bound)
1733 {
1734  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
1735  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
1736  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
1737  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
1738  return trunk_connection_requests_requeue(tconn, states, max, fail_bound);
1739 
1740  default:
1741  return 0;
1742  }
1743 }
1744 
1745 /** Signal a partial write
1746  *
1747  * Where there's high load, and the outbound write buffer is full
1748  *
1749  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1750  */
1751 void fr_trunk_request_signal_partial(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1752 {
1753  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1754 
1755  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_MUX(treq->pub.trunk),
1756  "%s can only be called from within request_mux handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
1757 
1758  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1759  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
1760  trunk_request_enter_partial(treq);
1761  break;
1762 
1763  default:
1764  return;
1765  }
1766 }
1767 
1768 /** Signal that the request was written to a connection successfully
1769  *
1770  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1771  */
1772 void fr_trunk_request_signal_sent(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1773 {
1774  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1775 
1776  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_MUX(treq->pub.trunk),
1777  "%s can only be called from within request_mux handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
1778 
1779  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1780  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING:
1781  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
1782  trunk_request_enter_sent(treq);
1783  break;
1784 
1785  default:
1786  return;
1787  }
1788 }
1789 
1790 /** Signal that a trunk request is complete
1791  *
1792  * The API client will be informed that the request is now complete.
1793  */
1794 void fr_trunk_request_signal_complete(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1795 {
1796  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1797 
1798  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1799 
1800  /*
1801  * We assume that if the request is being signalled
1802  * as complete from the demux function, that it was
1803  * a successful read.
1804  *
1805  * If this assumption turns out to be incorrect
1806  * then we need to add an argument to signal_complete
1807  * to indicate if this is a successful read.
1808  */
1809  if (IN_REQUEST_DEMUX(trunk)) trunk->pub.last_read_success = fr_time();
1810 
1811  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1812  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
1813  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING: /* Got immediate response, i.e. cached */
1814  trunk_request_enter_complete(treq);
1815  break;
1816 
1817  default:
1818  return;
1819  }
1820 }
1821 
1822 /** Signal that a trunk request failed
1823  *
1824  * The API client will be informed that the request has failed.
1825  */
1826 void fr_trunk_request_signal_fail(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1827 {
1828  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1829 
1830  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
1831 }
1832 
1833 /** Cancel a trunk request
1834  *
1835  * treq can be in any state, but requests to cancel if the treq is not in
1836  * the FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL or FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT state will be ignored.
1837  *
1838  * The complete or failed callbacks will not be called here, as it's assumed the request_t *
1839  * is now inviable as it's being cancelled.
1840  *
1841  * The free function however, is called, and that should be used to perform necessary
1842  * cleanup.
1843  *
1844  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1845  */
1846 void fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1847 {
1848  fr_trunk_t *trunk;
1849 
1850  /*
1851  * Ensure treq hasn't been freed
1852  */
1853  (void)talloc_get_type_abort(treq, fr_trunk_request_t);
1854 
1855  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1856 
1857  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!IN_HANDLER(treq->pub.trunk),
1858  "%s cannot be called within a handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
1859 
1860  trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
1861 
1862  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1863  /*
1864  * We don't call the complete or failed callbacks
1865  * as the request and rctx are no longer viable.
1866  */
1867  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
1868  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
1869  {
1870  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
1871 
1872  /*
1873  * Don't allow connection state changes
1874  */
1875  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
1876  trunk_request_enter_cancel(treq, FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_SIGNAL);
1877  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL,
1878  "Bad state %s after cancellation",
1879  fr_table_str_by_value(fr_trunk_request_states, treq->pub.state, "<INVALID>"))) {
1880  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1881  return;
1882  }
1883  /*
1884  * No cancel muxer. We're done.
1885  *
1886  * If we do have a cancel mux function,
1887  * the next time this connection becomes
1888  * writable, we'll call the cancel mux
1889  * function.
1890  *
1891  * We don't run the complete or failed
1892  * callbacks here as the request is
1893  * being cancelled.
1894  */
1895  if (!trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux) {
1896  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1897  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq);
1898  }
1899  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
1900  }
1901  break;
1902 
1903  /*
1904  * We're already in the process of cancelling a
1905  * request, so ignore duplicate signals.
1906  */
1907  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
1908  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL:
1909  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT:
1910  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_COMPLETE:
1911  break;
1912 
1913  /*
1914  * For any other state, we just release the request
1915  * from its current connection and free it.
1916  */
1917  default:
1918  trunk_request_enter_unassigned(treq);
1919  fr_trunk_request_free(&treq);
1920  break;
1921  }
1922 }
1923 
1924 /** Signal a partial cancel write
1925  *
1926  * Where there's high load, and the outbound write buffer is full
1927  *
1928  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1929  */
1930 void fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_partial(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1931 {
1932  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1933 
1934  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_CANCEL_MUX(treq->pub.trunk),
1935  "%s can only be called from within request_cancel_mux handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
1936 
1937  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1938  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
1939  trunk_request_enter_cancel_partial(treq);
1940  break;
1941 
1942  default:
1943  return;
1944  }
1945 }
1946 
1947 /** Signal that a remote server has been notified of the cancellation
1948  *
1949  * Called from request_cancel_mux to indicate that the datastore has been informed
1950  * that the response is no longer needed.
1951  *
1952  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1953  */
1954 void fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_sent(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1955 {
1956  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1957 
1958  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_CANCEL_MUX(treq->pub.trunk),
1959  "%s can only be called from within request_cancel_mux handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
1960 
1961  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1962  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL:
1963  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL:
1964  trunk_request_enter_cancel_sent(treq);
1965  break;
1966 
1967  default:
1968  break;
1969  }
1970 }
1971 
1972 /** Signal that a remote server acked our cancellation
1973  *
1974  * Called from request_demux to indicate that it got an ack for the cancellation.
1975  *
1976  * @param[in] treq to signal state change for.
1977  */
1978 void fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_complete(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
1979 {
1980  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(treq->pub.trunk, "treq not associated with trunk")) return;
1981 
1982  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_DEMUX(treq->pub.trunk) || IN_REQUEST_CANCEL_MUX(treq->pub.trunk),
1983  "%s can only be called from within request_demux or request_cancel_mux handlers",
1984  __FUNCTION__)) return;
1985 
1986  switch (treq->pub.state) {
1987  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT:
1988  trunk_request_enter_cancel_complete(treq);
1989  break;
1990 
1991  default:
1992  break;
1993  }
1994 }
1995 
1996 /** If the trunk request is freed then update the target requests
1997  *
1998  * gperftools showed calling the request free function directly was slightly faster
1999  * than using talloc_free.
2000  *
2001  * @param[in] treq_to_free request.
2002  */
2003 void fr_trunk_request_free(fr_trunk_request_t **treq_to_free)
2004 {
2005  fr_trunk_request_t *treq = *treq_to_free;
2006  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
2007 
2008  if (unlikely(!treq)) return;
2009 
2010  /*
2011  * The only valid states a trunk request can be
2012  * freed from.
2013  */
2014  switch (treq->pub.state) {
2015  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT:
2016  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
2017  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_COMPLETE:
2018  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_FAILED:
2019  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_COMPLETE:
2020  break;
2021 
2022  default:
2023  if (!fr_cond_assert(0)) return;
2024  }
2025 
2026  /*
2027  * Zero out the pointer to prevent double frees
2028  */
2029  *treq_to_free = NULL;
2030 
2031  /*
2032  * Call the API client callback to free
2033  * any associated memory.
2034  */
2035  DO_REQUEST_FREE(treq);
2036 
2037  /*
2038  * Update the last above/below target stats
2039  * We only do this when we alloc or free
2040  * connections, or on connection
2041  * state changes.
2042  */
2043  trunk_requests_per_connection(NULL, NULL, treq->pub.trunk, fr_time(), false);
2044 
2045  /*
2046  * This tracks the total number of requests
2047  * allocated and not freed or returned to
2048  * the free list.
2049  */
2050  if (fr_cond_assert(trunk->pub.req_alloc > 0)) trunk->pub.req_alloc--;
2051 
2052  /*
2053  * No cleanup delay, means cleanup immediately
2054  */
2055  if (trunk->conf.req_cleanup_delay == 0) {
2056  treq->pub.state = FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT;
2057 
2058 #ifndef NDEBUG
2059  /*
2060  * Ensure anything parented off the treq
2061  * is freed. We do this to trigger
2062  * the destructors for the log entries.
2063  */
2064  talloc_free_children(treq);
2065 
2066  /*
2067  * State log should now be empty as entries
2068  * remove themselves from the dlist
2069  * on free.
2070  */
2071  fr_assert_msg(fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log) == 0,
2072  "Should have 0 remaining log entries, have %zu", fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log));
2073 #endif
2074 
2075  talloc_free(treq);
2076  return;
2077  }
2078 
2079  /*
2080  * Ensure anything parented off the treq
2081  * is freed.
2082  */
2083  talloc_free_children(treq);
2084 
2085 #ifndef NDEBUG
2086  /*
2087  * State log should now be empty as entries
2088  * remove themselves from the dlist
2089  * on free.
2090  */
2091  fr_assert_msg(fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log) == 0,
2092  "Should have 0 remaining log entries, have %zu", fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log));
2093 #endif
2094 
2095  /*
2096  *
2097  * Return the trunk request back to the init state.
2098  */
2099  *treq = (fr_trunk_request_t){
2100  .pub = {
2101  .state = FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT,
2102  .trunk = treq->pub.trunk,
2103  },
2104  .cancel_reason = FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_NONE,
2105  .last_freed = fr_time(),
2106 #ifndef NDEBUG
2107  .log = treq->log /* Keep the list head, to save reinitialisation */
2108 #endif
2109  };
2110 
2111  /*
2112  * Insert at the head, so that we can free
2113  * requests that have been unused for N
2114  * seconds from the tail.
2115  */
2116  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&trunk->free_requests, treq);
2117 }
2118 
2119 /** Actually free the trunk request
2120  *
2121  */
2122 static int _trunk_request_free(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
2123 {
2124  fr_trunk_t *trunk = treq->pub.trunk;
2125 
2126  switch (treq->pub.state) {
2127  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT:
2128  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_UNASSIGNED:
2129  break;
2130 
2131  default:
2132  fr_assert(0);
2133  break;
2134  }
2135 
2136  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->free_requests, treq);
2137 
2138  return 0;
2139 }
2140 
2141 /** (Pre-)Allocate a new trunk request
2142  *
2143  * If trunk->conf.req_pool_headers or trunk->conf.req_pool_size are not zero then the
2144  * request will be a talloc pool, which can be used to hold the preq.
2145  *
2146  * @note Do not use MEM to check the result of this allocated as it may fail for
2147  * non-fatal reasons.
2148  *
2149  * @param[in] trunk to add request to.
2150  * @param[in] request to wrap in a trunk request (treq).
2151  * @return
2152  * - A newly allocated request.
2153  * - NULL if too many requests are allocated.
2154  */
2155 fr_trunk_request_t *fr_trunk_request_alloc(fr_trunk_t *trunk, request_t *request)
2156 {
2157  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
2158 
2159  /*
2160  * The number of treqs currently allocated
2161  * exceeds the maximum number allowed.
2162  */
2163  if (trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn && trunk->conf.max) {
2164  uint64_t limit;
2165 
2166  limit = trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn * trunk->conf.max;
2167  if (trunk->pub.req_alloc >= limit) {
2168  RATE_LIMIT_LOCAL_ROPTIONAL(&trunk->limit_max_requests_alloc_log,
2169  RWARN, WARN, "Refusing to alloc requests - "
2170  "Limit of %"PRIu64" (max = %u * per_connection_max = %u) "
2171  "requests reached",
2172  limit, trunk->conf.max, trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn);
2173  return NULL;
2174  }
2175  }
2176 
2177  /*
2178  * Allocate or reuse an existing request
2179  */
2180  treq = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->free_requests);
2181  if (treq) {
2182  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->free_requests, treq);
2183  fr_assert(treq->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT);
2184  fr_assert(treq->pub.trunk == trunk);
2185  fr_assert(treq->pub.tconn == NULL);
2186  fr_assert(treq->cancel_reason == FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_NONE);
2187  fr_assert(treq->last_freed > 0);
2188  trunk->pub.req_alloc_reused++;
2189  } else {
2190  MEM(treq = talloc_pooled_object(trunk, fr_trunk_request_t,
2191  trunk->conf.req_pool_headers, trunk->conf.req_pool_size));
2192  talloc_set_destructor(treq, _trunk_request_free);
2193 
2194  *treq = (fr_trunk_request_t){
2195  .pub = {
2196  .state = FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT,
2197  .trunk = trunk
2198  },
2199  .cancel_reason = FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_NONE
2200  };
2201  trunk->pub.req_alloc_new++;
2202 #ifndef NDEBUG
2203  fr_dlist_init(&treq->log, fr_trunk_request_state_log_t, entry);
2204 #endif
2205  }
2206 
2207  trunk->pub.req_alloc++;
2208  treq->id = atomic_fetch_add_explicit(&request_counter, 1, memory_order_relaxed);
2209  /* heap_id - initialised when treq inserted into pending */
2210  /* list - empty */
2211  /* preq - populated later */
2212  /* rctx - populated later */
2213  treq->pub.request = request;
2214 
2215  return treq;
2216 }
2217 
2218 /** Enqueue a request that needs data written to the trunk
2219  *
2220  * When a request_t * needs to make an asynchronous request to an external datastore
2221  * it should call this function, specifying a preq (protocol request) containing
2222  * the data necessary to request information from the external datastore, and an
2223  * rctx (resume ctx) used to hold the decoded response and/or any error codes.
2224  *
2225  * After a treq is successfully enqueued it will either be assigned immediately
2226  * to the pending queue of a connection, or if no connections are available,
2227  * (depending on the trunk configuration) the treq will be placed in the trunk's
2228  * global backlog.
2229  *
2230  * After receiving a positive return code from this function the caller should
2231  * immediately yield, to allow the various timers and I/O handlers that drive tconn
2232  * (trunk connection) and treq state changes to be called.
2233  *
2234  * When a tconn becomes writable (or the trunk is configured to be always writable)
2235  * the #fr_trunk_request_mux_t callback will be called to dequeue, encode and
2236  * send any pending requests for that tconn. The #fr_trunk_request_mux_t callback
2237  * is also responsible for tracking the outbound requests to allow the
2238  * #fr_trunk_request_demux_t callback to match inbound responses with the original
2239  * treq. Once the #fr_trunk_request_mux_t callback is done processing the treq
2240  * it signals what state the treq should enter next using one of the
2241  * fr_trunk_request_signal_* functions.
2242  *
2243  * When a tconn becomes readable the user specified #fr_trunk_request_demux_t
2244  * callback is called to process any responses, match them with the original treq.
2245  * and signal what state they should enter next using one of the
2246  * fr_trunk_request_signal_* functions.
2247  *
2248  * @param[in,out] treq_out A trunk request handle. If the memory pointed to
2249  * is NULL, a new treq will be allocated.
2250  * Otherwise treq should point to memory allocated
2251  * with fr_trunk_request_alloc.
2252  * @param[in] trunk to enqueue request on.
2253  * @param[in] request to enqueue.
2254  * @param[in] preq Protocol request to write out. Will be freed when
2255  * treq is freed. Should ideally be parented by the
2256  * treq if possible.
2257  * Use #fr_trunk_request_alloc for pre-allocation of
2258  * the treq.
2259  * @param[in] rctx The resume context to write any result to.
2260  * @return
2261  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK.
2262  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG.
2263  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY.
2264  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE
2265  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL
2266  */
2267 fr_trunk_enqueue_t fr_trunk_request_enqueue(fr_trunk_request_t **treq_out, fr_trunk_t *trunk,
2268  request_t *request, void *preq, void *rctx)
2269 {
2270  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = NULL;
2271  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
2272  fr_trunk_enqueue_t ret;
2273 
2274  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!IN_HANDLER(trunk),
2275  "%s cannot be called within a handler", __FUNCTION__)) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2276 
2277  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!*treq_out || ((*treq_out)->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT),
2278  "%s requests must be in \"init\" state", __FUNCTION__)) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2279 
2280  /*
2281  * If delay_start was set, we may need
2282  * to insert the timer for the connection manager.
2283  */
2284  if (unlikely(!trunk->started)) {
2285  if (fr_trunk_start(trunk) < 0) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2286  }
2287 
2288  ret = trunk_request_check_enqueue(&tconn, trunk, request);
2289  switch (ret) {
2290  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK:
2291  if (*treq_out) {
2292  treq = *treq_out;
2293  } else {
2294  MEM(*treq_out = treq = fr_trunk_request_alloc(trunk, request));
2295  }
2296  treq->pub.preq = preq;
2297  treq->pub.rctx = rctx;
2298  if (trunk->conf.always_writable) {
2299  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
2300  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, true);
2301  trunk_connection_writable(tconn);
2302  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
2303  } else {
2304  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, true);
2305  }
2306  break;
2307 
2308  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG:
2309  if (*treq_out) {
2310  treq = *treq_out;
2311  } else {
2312  MEM(*treq_out = treq = fr_trunk_request_alloc(trunk, request));
2313  }
2314  treq->pub.preq = preq;
2315  treq->pub.rctx = rctx;
2316  trunk_request_enter_backlog(treq, true);
2317  break;
2318 
2319  default:
2320  /*
2321  * If a trunk request was provided
2322  * populate the preq and rctx fields
2323  * so that if it's freed with
2324  * fr_trunk_request_free, the free
2325  * function works as intended.
2326  */
2327  if (*treq_out) {
2328  treq = *treq_out;
2329  treq->pub.preq = preq;
2330  treq->pub.rctx = rctx;
2331  }
2332  return ret;
2333  }
2334 
2335  return ret;
2336 }
2337 
2338 /** Re-enqueue a request on the same connection
2339  *
2340  * If the treq has been sent, we assume that we're being signalled to requeue
2341  * because something outside of the trunk API has determined that a retransmission
2342  * is required. The easiest way to perform that retransmission is to clean up
2343  * any tracking information for the request, and the requeue it for transmission.
2344  *
2345  * IF re-queueing fails, the request will enter the fail state. It should not be
2346  * accessed if this occurs.
2347  *
2348  * @param[in] treq to requeue (retransmit).
2349  * @return
2350  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK.
2351  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE - Connection cannot service requests.
2352  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL - Request isn't in a valid state to be reassigned.
2353  */
2354 fr_trunk_enqueue_t fr_trunk_request_requeue(fr_trunk_request_t *treq)
2355 {
2356  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = treq->pub.tconn; /* Existing conn */
2357 
2358  if (!tconn) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2359 
2360  if (!IS_SERVICEABLE(tconn)) {
2361  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
2362  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE;
2363  }
2364 
2365  switch (treq->pub.state) {
2366  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL:
2367  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT:
2368  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
2369  trunk_request_enter_cancel(treq, FR_TRUNK_CANCEL_REASON_REQUEUE);
2370  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, false);
2371  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
2372  break;
2373 
2374  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG: /* Do nothing.... */
2375  case FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING: /* Do nothing.... */
2376  break;
2377 
2378  default:
2379  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
2380  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2381  }
2382 
2383  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK;
2384 }
2385 
2386 /** Enqueue additional requests on a specific connection
2387  *
2388  * This may be used to create a series of requests on a single connection, or to generate
2389  * in-band status checks.
2390  *
2391  * @note If conf->always_writable, then the muxer will be called immediately. The caller
2392  * must be able to handle multiple calls to its muxer gracefully.
2393  *
2394  * @param[in,out] treq_out A trunk request handle. If the memory pointed to
2395  * is NULL, a new treq will be allocated.
2396  * Otherwise treq should point to memory allocated
2397  * with fr_trunk_request_alloc.
2398  * @param[in] tconn to enqueue request on.
2399  * @param[in] request to enqueue.
2400  * @param[in] preq Protocol request to write out. Will be freed when
2401  * treq is freed. Should ideally be parented by the
2402  * treq if possible.
2403  * Use #fr_trunk_request_alloc for pre-allocation of
2404  * the treq.
2405  * @param[in] rctx The resume context to write any result to.
2406  * @param[in] ignore_limits Ignore max_req_per_conn. Useful to force status
2407  * checks through even if the connection is at capacity.
2408  * Will also allow enqueuing on "inactive", "draining",
2409  * "draining-to-free" connections.
2410  * @return
2411  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK.
2412  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY - At max_req_per_conn_limit
2413  * - FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE - Connection cannot service requests.
2414  */
2415 fr_trunk_enqueue_t fr_trunk_request_enqueue_on_conn(fr_trunk_request_t **treq_out, fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn,
2416  request_t *request, void *preq, void *rctx,
2417  bool ignore_limits)
2418 {
2419  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
2420  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2421 
2422  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!*treq_out || ((*treq_out)->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_INIT),
2423  "%s requests must be in \"init\" state", __FUNCTION__)) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL;
2424 
2425  if (!IS_SERVICEABLE(tconn)) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE;
2426 
2427  /*
2428  * Limits check
2429  */
2430  if (!ignore_limits) {
2431  if (trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn &&
2432  (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) >=
2433  trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn)) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY;
2434 
2435  if (tconn->pub.state != FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY;
2436  }
2437 
2438  if (*treq_out) {
2439  treq = *treq_out;
2440  } else {
2441  MEM(*treq_out = treq = fr_trunk_request_alloc(trunk, request));
2442  }
2443 
2444  treq->pub.preq = preq;
2445  treq->pub.rctx = rctx;
2446  treq->bound_to_conn = true; /* Don't let the request be transferred */
2447 
2448  if (trunk->conf.always_writable) {
2449  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
2450  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, true);
2451  trunk_connection_writable(tconn);
2452  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
2453  } else {
2454  trunk_request_enter_pending(treq, tconn, true);
2455  }
2456 
2457  return FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK;
2458 }
2459 
2460 #ifndef NDEBUG
2461 /** Used for sanity checks to ensure all log entries have been freed
2462  *
2463  */
2464 static int _state_log_entry_free(fr_trunk_request_state_log_t *slog)
2465 {
2466  fr_dlist_remove(slog->log_head, slog);
2467 
2468  return 0;
2469 }

2471 void trunk_request_state_log_entry_add(char const *function, int line,
2472  fr_trunk_request_t *treq, fr_trunk_request_state_t new)
2473 {
2474  fr_trunk_request_state_log_t *slog = NULL;
2475 
2476  if (fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log) >= FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_LOG_MAX) {
2477  slog = fr_dlist_head(&treq->log);
2478  fr_assert_msg(slog, "slog list head NULL but element counter was %zu",
2479  fr_dlist_num_elements(&treq->log));
2480  (void)fr_dlist_remove(&treq->log, slog); /* Returns NULL when removing the list head */
2481  memset(slog, 0, sizeof(*slog));
2482  } else {
2483  MEM(slog = talloc_zero(treq, fr_trunk_request_state_log_t));
2484  talloc_set_destructor(slog, _state_log_entry_free);
2485  }
2486 
2487  slog->log_head = &treq->log;
2488  slog->from = treq->pub.state;
2489  slog->to = new;
2490  slog->function = function;
2491  slog->line = line;
2492  if (treq->pub.tconn) {
2493  slog->tconn = treq->pub.tconn;
2494  slog->tconn_id = treq->pub.tconn->pub.conn->id;
2495  slog->tconn_state = treq->pub.tconn->pub.state;
2496  }
2497 
2498  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&treq->log, slog);
2499 
2500 }

2502 void fr_trunk_request_state_log(fr_log_t const *log, fr_log_type_t log_type, char const *file, int line,
2503  fr_trunk_request_t const *treq)
2504 {
2505  fr_trunk_request_state_log_t *slog = NULL;
2506 
2507  int i;
2508 
2509  for (slog = fr_dlist_head(&treq->log), i = 0;
2510  slog;
2511  slog = fr_dlist_next(&treq->log, slog), i++) {
2512  fr_log(log, log_type, file, line, "[%u] %s:%i - in conn %"PRIu64" in state %s - %s -> %s",
2513  i, slog->function, slog->line,
2514  slog->tconn_id,
2515  slog->tconn ? fr_table_str_by_value(fr_trunk_connection_states,
2516  slog->tconn_state, "<INVALID>") : "none",
2517  fr_table_str_by_value(fr_trunk_request_states, slog->from, "<INVALID>"),
2518  fr_table_str_by_value(fr_trunk_request_states, slog->to, "<INVALID>"));
2519  }
2520 }
2521 #endif

2523 /** Return the count number of connections in the specified states
2524  *
2525  * @param[in] trunk to retrieve counts for.
2526  * @param[in] conn_state One or more #fr_trunk_connection_state_t states or'd together.
2527  * @return The number of connections in the specified states.
2528  */
2529 uint16_t fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(fr_trunk_t *trunk, int conn_state)
2530 {
2531  uint16_t count = 0;
2532 
2533  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->init);
2534  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->connecting);
2535  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) count += fr_heap_num_elements(trunk->active);
2536  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->full);
2537  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->inactive);
2538  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->inactive_draining);
2539  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->closed);
2540  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->draining);
2541  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->draining_to_free);
2542 
2543  return count;
2544 }
2545 
2546 /** Return the count number of requests associated with a trunk connection
2547  *
2548  * @param[in] tconn to return request count for.
2549  * @param[in] req_state One or more request states or'd together.
2550  *
2551  * @return The number of requests in the specified states, associated with a tconn.
2552  */
2553 uint32_t fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(fr_trunk_connection_t const *tconn, int req_state)
2554 {
2555  uint32_t count = 0;
2556 
2557  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING) count += fr_heap_num_elements(tconn->pending);
2558  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL) count += tconn->partial ? 1 : 0;
2559  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&tconn->sent);
2560  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&tconn->cancel);
2561  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL) count += tconn->cancel_partial ? 1 : 0;
2562  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT) count += fr_dlist_num_elements(&tconn->cancel_sent);
2563 
2564  return count;
2565 }

2567 /** Automatically mark a connection as inactive
2568  *
2569  * @param[in] tconn to potentially mark as inactive.
2570  */
2571 static inline void trunk_connection_auto_full(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2572 {
2573  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2574  uint32_t count;
2575 
2576  if (tconn->pub.state != FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) return;
2577 
2578  /*
2579  * Enforces max_req_per_conn
2580  */
2581  if (trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn > 0) {
2582  count = fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL);
2583  if (count >= trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn) trunk_connection_enter_full(tconn);
2584  }
2585 }
2586 
2587 /** Return whether a trunk connection should currently be considered full
2588  *
2589  * @param[in] tconn to check.
2590  * @return
2591  * - true if the connection is full.
2592  * - false if the connection is not full.
2593  */
2594 static inline bool trunk_connection_is_full(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2595 {
2596  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2597  uint32_t count;
2598 
2599  /*
2600  * Enforces max_req_per_conn
2601  */
2602  count = fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL);
2603  if ((trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn == 0) || (count < trunk->conf.max_req_per_conn)) return false;
2604 
2605  return true;
2606 }
2607 
2608 /** Automatically mark a connection as active or reconnect it
2609  *
2610  * @param[in] tconn to potentially mark as active or reconnect.
2611  */
2612 static inline void trunk_connection_auto_unfull(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2613 {
2614  if (tconn->pub.state != FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL) return;
2615 
2616  /*
2617  * Enforces max_req_per_conn
2618  */
2619  if (!trunk_connection_is_full(tconn)) trunk_connection_enter_active(tconn);
2620 }
2621 
2622 /** A connection is readable. Call the request_demux function to read pending requests
2623  *
2624  */
2625 static inline void trunk_connection_readable(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2626 {
2627  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2628 
2629  DO_REQUEST_DEMUX(tconn);
2630 }
2631 
2632 /** A connection is writable. Call the request_mux function to write pending requests
2633  *
2634  */
2635 static inline void trunk_connection_writable(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2636 {
2637  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2638 
2639  /*
2640  * Call the cancel_sent function (if we have one)
2641  * to inform a backend datastore we no longer
2642  * care about the result
2643  */
2644  if (trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux && fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn,
2645  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL |
2646  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL)) {
2647  DO_REQUEST_CANCEL_MUX(tconn);
2648  }
2649  if (!fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn,
2650  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING |
2651  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL)) return;
2652  DO_REQUEST_MUX(tconn);
2653 }
2654 
2655 /** Update the registrations for I/O events we're interested in
2656  *
2657  */
2658 static void trunk_connection_event_update(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2659 {
2660  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2661  fr_trunk_connection_event_t events = FR_TRUNK_CONN_EVENT_NONE;
2662 
2663  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2664  /*
2665  * We only register I/O events if the trunk connection is
2666  * in one of these states.
2667  *
2668  * For the other states the trunk shouldn't be processing
2669  * requests.
2670  */
2671  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2672  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2673  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2674  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
2675  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
2676  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE:
2677  /*
2678  * If the connection is always writable,
2679  * then we don't care about write events.
2680  */
2681  if (!trunk->conf.always_writable &&
2682  fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn,
2683  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PARTIAL |
2684  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING |
2685  (trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux ?
2686  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL |
2687  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_PARTIAL : 0)) > 0) {
2688  events |= FR_TRUNK_CONN_EVENT_WRITE;
2689  }
2690 
2691  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn,
2692  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_SENT |
2693  (trunk->funcs.request_cancel_mux ?
2694  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_CANCEL_SENT : 0)) > 0) {
2695  events |= FR_TRUNK_CONN_EVENT_READ;
2696  }
2697  break;
2698 
2699  default:
2700  break;
2701  }
2702 
2703  if (tconn->events != events) {
2704  /*
2705  * There may be a fatal error which results
2706  * in the connection being freed.
2707  *
2708  * Stop that from happening until after
2709  * we're done using it.
2710  */
2711  fr_connection_signals_pause(tconn->pub.conn);
2712  DO_CONNECTION_NOTIFY(tconn, events);
2713  tconn->events = events;
2714  fr_connection_signals_resume(tconn->pub.conn);
2715  }
2716 }
2717 
2718 /** Remove a trunk connection from whichever list it's currently in
2719  *
2720  * @param[in] tconn to remove.
2721  */
2722 static void trunk_connection_remove(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2723 {
2724  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2725 
2726  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2727  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2728  {
2729  int ret;
2730 
2731  ret = fr_heap_extract(trunk->active, tconn);
2732  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(ret == 0, "Failed extracting conn from active heap: %s", fr_strerror())) return;
2733  }
2734  return;
2735 
2736  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT:
2737  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->init, tconn);
2738  break;
2739 
2740  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING:
2741  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->connecting, tconn);
2742  return;
2743 
2744  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
2745  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->closed, tconn);
2746  return;
2747 
2748  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2749  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->full, tconn);
2750  return;
2751 
2752  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2753  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->inactive, tconn);
2754  return;
2755 
2756  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
2757  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->inactive_draining, tconn);
2758  return;
2759 
2760  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
2761  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->draining, tconn);
2762  return;
2763 
2764  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE:
2765  fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->draining_to_free, tconn);
2766  return;
2767 
2768  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED:
2769  return;
2770  }
2771 }
2772 
2773 /** Transition a connection to the full state
2774  *
2775  * Called whenever a trunk connection is at the maximum number of requests.
2776  * Removes the connection from the connected heap, and places it in the full list.
2777  */
2778 static void trunk_connection_enter_full(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2779 {
2780  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2781 
2782  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2783  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2784  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2785  break;
2786 
2787  default:
2788  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL);
2789  }
2790 
2791  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->full, tconn);
2792  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL, DEBUG2);
2793 }
2794 
2795 /** Transition a connection to the inactive state
2796  *
2797  * Called whenever the API client wants to stop new requests being enqueued
2798  * on a trunk connection.
2799  */
2800 static void trunk_connection_enter_inactive(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2801 {
2802  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2803 
2804  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2805  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2806  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2807  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2808  break;
2809 
2810  default:
2811  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE);
2812  }
2813 
2814  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->inactive, tconn);
2815  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE, DEBUG2);
2816 }
2817 
2818 /** Transition a connection to the inactive-draining state
2819  *
2820  * Called whenever the trunk manager wants to drain an inactive connection
2821  * of its requests.
2822  */
2823 static void trunk_connection_enter_inactive_draining(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2824 {
2825  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2826 
2827  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2828  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2829  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
2830  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2831  break;
2832 
2833  default:
2834  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING);
2835  }
2836 
2837  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->inactive_draining, tconn);
2838  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING, INFO);
2839 
2840  /*
2841  * Immediately re-enqueue all pending
2842  * requests, so the connection is drained
2843  * quicker.
2844  */
2845  trunk_connection_requests_requeue(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING, 0, false);
2846 }
2847 
2848 /** Transition a connection to the draining state
2849  *
2850  * Removes the connection from the active heap so it won't be assigned any new
2851  * connections.
2852  */
2853 static void trunk_connection_enter_draining(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2854 {
2855  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2856 
2857  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2858  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2859  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2860  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2861  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
2862  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2863  break;
2864 
2865  default:
2866  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING);
2867  }
2868 
2869  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->draining, tconn);
2870  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING, INFO);
2871 
2872  /*
2873  * Immediately re-enqueue all pending
2874  * requests, so the connection is drained
2875  * quicker.
2876  */
2877  trunk_connection_requests_requeue(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING, 0, false);
2878 }
2879 
2880 /** Transition a connection to the draining-to-reconnect state
2881  *
2882  * Removes the connection from the active heap so it won't be assigned any new
2883  * connections.
2884  */
2885 static void trunk_connection_enter_draining_to_free(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2886 {
2887  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2888 
2889  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2890  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
2891  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2892  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2893  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
2894  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
2895  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2896  break;
2897 
2898  default:
2899  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE);
2900  }
2901 
2902  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->draining_to_free, tconn);
2903  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE, INFO);
2904 
2905  /*
2906  * Immediately re-enqueue all pending
2907  * requests, so the connection is drained
2908  * quicker.
2909  */
2910  trunk_connection_requests_requeue(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING, 0, false);
2911 }
2912 
2913 
2914 /** Transition a connection back to the active state
2915  *
2916  * This should only be called on a connection which is in the full state,
2917  * inactive state, draining state or connecting state.
2918  */
2919 static void trunk_connection_enter_active(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
2920 {
2921  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2922  int ret;
2923 
2924  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2925  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
2926  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
2927  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
2928  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
2929  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2930  break;
2931 
2932  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING:
2933  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
2934  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
2935  break;
2936 
2937  default:
2938  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE);
2939  }
2940 
2941  ret = fr_heap_insert(trunk->active, tconn); /* re-insert into the active heap*/
2942  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(ret == 0, "Failed inserting connection into active heap: %s", fr_strerror())) {
2943  trunk_connection_enter_inactive_draining(tconn);
2944  return;
2945  }
2946 
2947  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE, DEBUG2);
2948 
2949  /*
2950  * Reorder the connections
2951  */
2952  CONN_REORDER(tconn);
2953 
2954  /*
2955  * Rebalance requests
2956  */
2957  trunk_rebalance(trunk);
2958 
2959  /*
2960  * We place requests into the backlog
2961  * because there were no connections
2962  * available to handle them.
2963  *
2964  * If a connection has become active
2965  * chances are those backlogged requests
2966  * can now be enqueued, so try and do
2967  * that now.
2968  *
2969  * If there's requests sitting in the
2970  * backlog indefinitely, it's because
2971  * they were inserted there erroneously
2972  * when there were active connections
2973  * which could have handled them.
2974  */
2975  trunk_backlog_drain(trunk);
2976 }
2977 
2978 /** Connection transitioned to the the init state
2979  *
2980  * Reflect the connection state change in the lists we use to track connections.
2981  *
2982  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
2983  *
2984  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
2985  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
2986  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
2987  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
2988  */
2989 static void _trunk_connection_on_init(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
2990  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
2991  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
2992  void *uctx)
2993 {
2994  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
2995  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
2996 
2997  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
2998  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED:
2999  break;
3000 
3001  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
3002  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
3003  break;
3004 
3005  default:
3006  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT);
3007  }
3008 
3009  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->init, tconn);
3010  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT, DEBUG2);
3011 }
3012 
3013 /** Connection transitioned to the connecting state
3014  *
3015  * Reflect the connection state change in the lists we use to track connections.
3016  *
3017  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
3018  *
3019  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3020  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3021  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3022  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3023  */
3024 static void _trunk_connection_on_connecting(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
3025  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
3026  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
3027  void *uctx)
3028 {
3029  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3030  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3031 
3032  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3033  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT:
3034  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
3035  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
3036  break;
3037 
3038  default:
3039  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING);
3040  }
3041 
3042  /*
3043  * If a connection just entered the
3044  * connecting state, it should have
3045  * no requests associated with it.
3046  */
3047  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
3048 
3049  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->connecting, tconn); /* MUST remain a head insertion for reconnect logic */
3050  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING, INFO);
3051 }
