3053 /** Connection transitioned to the shutdown state
3054  *
3055  * If we're not already in the draining-to-free state, transition there now.
3056  *
3057  * The idea is that if something signalled the connection to shutdown, we need
3058  * to reflect that by dequeuing any pending requests, not accepting new ones,
3059  * and waiting for the existing requests to complete.
3060  *
3061  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
3062  *
3063  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3064  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3065  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3066  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3067  */
3068 static void _trunk_connection_on_shutdown(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
3069  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
3070  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
3071  void *uctx)
3072 {
3073  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3074 
3075  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3076  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE: /* Do Nothing */
3077  return;
3078 
3079  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE: /* Transition to draining-to-free */
3080  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
3081  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
3082  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
3083  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
3084  break;
3085 
3086  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT:
3087  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING:
3088  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
3089  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED:
3090  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE);
3091  }
3092 
3093  trunk_connection_enter_draining_to_free(tconn);
3094 }
3095 
3096 /** Trigger a reconnection of the trunk connection
3097  *
3098  * @param[in] el Event list the timer was inserted into.
3099  * @param[in] now Current time.
3100  * @param[in] uctx The tconn.
3101  */
3102 static void _trunk_connection_lifetime_expire(UNUSED fr_event_list_t *el, UNUSED fr_time_t now, void *uctx)
3103 {
3104  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3105 
3106  trunk_connection_enter_draining_to_free(tconn);
3107 }
3108 
3109 /** Connection transitioned to the connected state
3110  *
3111  * Reflect the connection state change in the lists we use to track connections.
3112  *
3113  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
3114  *
3115  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3116  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3117  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3118  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3119  */
3120 static void _trunk_connection_on_connected(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
3121  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
3122  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
3123  void *uctx)
3124 {
3125  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3126  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3127 
3128  /*
3129  * If a connection was just connected,
3130  * it should have no requests associated
3131  * with it.
3132  */
3133  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
3134 
3135  /*
3136  * Set here, as the active state can
3137  * be transitioned to from full and
3138  * draining too.
3139  */
3140  trunk->pub.last_connected = fr_time();
3141 
3142  /*
3143  * Insert a timer to reconnect the
3144  * connection periodically.
3145  */
3146  if (trunk->conf.lifetime > 0) {
3147  if (fr_event_timer_in(tconn, trunk->el, &tconn->lifetime_ev,
3148  trunk->conf.lifetime, _trunk_connection_lifetime_expire, tconn) < 0) {
3149  PERROR("Failed inserting connection reconnection timer event, halting connection");
3150  fr_connection_signal_shutdown(tconn->pub.conn);
3151  return;
3152  }
3153  }
3154 
3155  trunk_connection_enter_active(tconn);
3156 }
3157 
3158 /** Connection failed after it was connected
3159  *
3160  * Reflect the connection state change in the lists we use to track connections.
3161  *
3162  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
3163  *
3164  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3165  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3166  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3167  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3168  */
3169 static void _trunk_connection_on_closed(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
3170  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
3171  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
3172  void *uctx)
3173 {
3174  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3175  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3176  bool need_requeue = false;
3177 
3178  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3179  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
3180  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
3181  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
3182  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING:
3183  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
3184  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE:
3185  need_requeue = true;
3186  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
3187  break;
3188 
3189  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT: /* Initialisation failed */
3190  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING:
3191  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
3192  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
3193  break;
3194 
3195  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
3196  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED: /* Can't move backwards? */
3197  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED);
3198  }
3199 
3200  fr_dlist_insert_head(&trunk->closed, tconn); /* MUST remain a head insertion for reconnect logic */
3201  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED, INFO);
3202 
3203  /*
3204  * Now *AFTER* the connection has been
3205  * removed from the active, pool
3206  * re-enqueue the requests.
3207  */
3208  if (need_requeue) trunk_connection_requests_requeue(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL, 0, true);
3209 
3210  /*
3211  * There should be no requests left on this
3212  * connection. They should have all been
3213  * moved off or failed.
3214  */
3215  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
3216 
3217  /*
3218  * Clear statistics and flags
3219  */
3220  tconn->sent_count = 0;
3221 
3222  /*
3223  * Remove the reconnect event
3224  */
3225  if (trunk->conf.lifetime > 0) fr_event_timer_delete(&tconn->lifetime_ev);
3226 
3227  /*
3228  * Remove the I/O events
3229  */
3230  trunk_connection_event_update(tconn);
3231 }
3232 
3233 /** Connection failed
3234  *
3235  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3236  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3237  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3238  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3239  */
3240 static void _trunk_connection_on_failed(fr_connection_t *conn,
3241  fr_connection_state_t prev,
3242  fr_connection_state_t state,
3243  void *uctx)
3244 {
3245  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3246  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3247 
3248  /*
3249  * Need to set this first as it
3250  * determines whether requests are
3251  * re-queued or fail outright.
3252  */
3253  trunk->pub.last_failed = fr_time();
3254 
3255  /*
3256  * Failed in the init state, transition the
3257  * connection to closed, else we get an
3258  * INIT -> INIT transition which triggers
3259  * an assert.
3260  */
3261  if (prev == FR_CONNECTION_STATE_INIT) _trunk_connection_on_closed(conn, prev, state, uctx);
3262 
3263  /*
3264  * See what the state of the trunk is
3265  * if there are no connections that could
3266  * potentially accept requests in the near
3267  * future, then fail all the requests in the
3268  * trunk backlog.
3269  */
3270  if ((state == FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CONNECTED) &&
3271  (fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(trunk,
3272  (FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE |
3273  FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL |
3274  FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING)) == 0)) trunk_backlog_drain(trunk);
3275 }
3276 
3277 /** Connection transitioned to the halted state
3278  *
3279  * Remove the connection remove all lists, as it's likely about to be freed.
3280  *
3281  * Setting the trunk back to the init state ensures that if the code is ever
3282  * refactored and #fr_connection_signal_reconnect is used after a connection
3283  * is halted, then everything is maintained in a valid state.
3284  *
3285  * @note This function is only called from the connection API as a watcher.
3286  *
3287  * @param[in] conn The connection which changes state.
3288  * @param[in] prev The connection is was in.
3289  * @param[in] state The connection is now in.
3290  * @param[in] uctx The fr_trunk_connection_t wrapping the connection.
3291  */
3292 static void _trunk_connection_on_halted(UNUSED fr_connection_t *conn,
3293  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t prev,
3294  UNUSED fr_connection_state_t state,
3295  void *uctx)
3296 {
3297  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_connection_t);
3298  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3299 
3300  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3301  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT:
3302  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED:
3303  trunk_connection_remove(tconn);
3304  break;
3305 
3306  default:
3307  CONN_BAD_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED);
3308  }
3309 
3310  /*
3311  * It began life in the halted state,
3312  * and will end life in the halted state.
3313  */
3314  CONN_STATE_TRANSITION(FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED, DEBUG2);
3315 
3316  /*
3317  * There should be no requests left on this
3318  * connection. They should have all been
3319  * moved off or failed.
3320  */
3321  fr_assert(fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0);
3322 
3323  /*
3324  * And free the connection...
3325  */
3326  if (trunk->in_handler) {
3327  /*
3328  * ...later.
3329  */
3330  fr_dlist_insert_tail(&trunk->to_free, tconn);
3331  return;
3332  }
3333  talloc_free(tconn);
3334 }
3335 
3336 /** Free a connection
3337  *
3338  * Enforces orderly free order of children of the tconn
3339  */
3340 static int _trunk_connection_free(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3341 {
3342  fr_assert(tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED);
3343  fr_assert(!fr_dlist_entry_in_list(&tconn->entry)); /* Should not be in a list */
3344 
3345  /*
3346  * Loop over all the requests we gathered
3347  * and transition them to the failed state,
3348  * freeing them.
3349  *
3350  * Usually, requests will be re-queued when
3351  * a connection enters the closed state,
3352  * but in this case because the whole trunk
3353  * is being freed, we don't bother, and
3354  * just signal to the API client that the
3355  * requests failed.
3356  */
3357  if (tconn->pub.trunk->freeing) {
3358  fr_dlist_head_t to_fail;
3359  fr_trunk_request_t *treq = NULL;
3360 
3361  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&to_fail, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
3362 
3363  /*
3364  * Remove requests from this connection
3365  */
3366  trunk_connection_requests_dequeue(&to_fail, tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL, 0);
3367  while ((treq = fr_dlist_next(&to_fail, treq))) {
3368  fr_trunk_request_t *prev;
3369 
3370  prev = fr_dlist_remove(&to_fail, treq);
3371  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
3372  treq = prev;
3373  }
3374  }
3375 
3376  /*
3377  * Ensure we're not signalled by the connection
3378  * as it processes its backlog of state changes,
3379  * as we are about to be freed.
3380  */
3381  fr_connection_del_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_INIT, _trunk_connection_on_init);
3382  fr_connection_del_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CONNECTING, _trunk_connection_on_connecting);
3383  fr_connection_del_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CONNECTED, _trunk_connection_on_connected);
3384  fr_connection_del_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CLOSED, _trunk_connection_on_closed);
3385  fr_connection_del_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_SHUTDOWN, _trunk_connection_on_shutdown);
3386  fr_connection_del_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_FAILED, _trunk_connection_on_failed);
3387  fr_connection_del_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_HALTED, _trunk_connection_on_halted);
3388 
3389  /*
3390  * This may return -1, indicating the free was deferred
3391  * this is fine. It just means the conn will be freed
3392  * after all the handlers have exited.
3393  */
3394  (void)talloc_free(tconn->pub.conn);
3395  tconn->pub.conn = NULL;
3396 
3397  return 0;
3398 }
3399 
3400 /** Attempt to spawn a new connection
3401  *
3402  * Calls the API client's alloc() callback to create a new fr_connection_t,
3403  * then inserts the connection into the 'connecting' list.
3404  *
3405  * @param[in] trunk to spawn connection in.
3406  * @param[in] now The current time.
3407  */
3408 static int trunk_connection_spawn(fr_trunk_t *trunk, fr_time_t now)
3409 {
3410  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn;
3411 
3412 
3413  /*
3414  * Call the API client's callback to create
3415  * a new fr_connection_t.
3416  */
3417  MEM(tconn = talloc_zero(trunk, fr_trunk_connection_t));
3418  tconn->pub.trunk = trunk;
3419  tconn->pub.state = FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED; /* All connections start in the halted state */
3420  tconn->heap_id = -1; /* Helps with asserts */
3421 
3422  /*
3423  * Allocate a new fr_connection_t or fail.
3424  */
3425  DO_CONNECTION_ALLOC(tconn);
3426 
3427  MEM(tconn->pending = fr_heap_talloc_alloc(tconn, _trunk_request_prioritise,
3428  fr_trunk_request_t, heap_id));
3429  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&tconn->sent, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
3430  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&tconn->cancel, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
3431  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&tconn->cancel_sent, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
3432 
3433  /*
3434  * OK, we have the connection, now setup watch
3435  * points so we know when it changes state.
3436  *
3437  * This lets us automatically move the tconn
3438  * between the different lists in the trunk
3439  * with minimum extra code.
3440  */
3441  fr_connection_add_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_INIT,
3442  _trunk_connection_on_init, false, tconn); /* Before init() has been called */
3443 
3444  fr_connection_add_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CONNECTING,
3445  _trunk_connection_on_connecting, false, tconn); /* After init() has been called */
3446 
3447  fr_connection_add_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CONNECTED,
3448  _trunk_connection_on_connected, false, tconn); /* After open() has been called */
3449 
3450  fr_connection_add_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_CLOSED,
3451  _trunk_connection_on_closed, false, tconn); /* Before close() has been called */
3452 
3453  fr_connection_add_watch_pre(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_FAILED,
3454  _trunk_connection_on_failed, false, tconn); /* Before failed() has been called */
3455 
3456  fr_connection_add_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_SHUTDOWN,
3457  _trunk_connection_on_shutdown, false, tconn); /* After shutdown() has been called */
3458 
3459  fr_connection_add_watch_post(tconn->pub.conn, FR_CONNECTION_STATE_HALTED,
3460  _trunk_connection_on_halted, false, tconn); /* About to be freed */
3461 
3462  talloc_set_destructor(tconn, _trunk_connection_free);
3463 
3464  fr_connection_signal_init(tconn->pub.conn); /* annnnd GO! */
3465 
3466  trunk->pub.last_open = now;
3467 
3468  return 0;
3469 }
3470 
3471 /** Pop a cancellation request off a connection's cancellation queue
3472  *
3473  * The request we return is advanced by the request moving out of the
3474  * cancel state and into the cancel_sent or cancel_complete state.
3475  *
3476  * One of these signalling functions must be called after the request
3477  * has been popped:
3478  *
3479  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_sent
3480  * The remote datastore has been informed, but we need to wait for acknowledgement.
3481  * The #fr_trunk_request_demux_t callback must handle the acks calling
3482  * #fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_complete when an ack is received.
3483  *
3484  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_cancel_complete
3485  * The request was cancelled and we don't need to wait, clean it up immediately.
3486  *
3487  * @param[out] treq_out to process
3488  * @param[in] tconn Connection to drain cancellation request from.
3489  * @return
3490  * - 1 if no more requests.
3491  * - 0 if a new request was written to treq_out.
3492  * - -1 if the connection was previously freed. Caller *MUST NOT* touch any
3493  * memory or requests associated with the connection.
3494  * - -2 if called outside of the cancel muxer.
3495  */
3496 int fr_trunk_connection_pop_cancellation(fr_trunk_request_t **treq_out, fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3497 {
3498  if (unlikely(tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED)) return -1;
3499 
3500  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_CANCEL_MUX(tconn->pub.trunk),
3501  "%s can only be called from within request_cancel_mux handler",
3502  __FUNCTION__)) return -2;
3503 
3504  *treq_out = tconn->cancel_partial ? tconn->cancel_partial : fr_dlist_head(&tconn->cancel);
3505  if (!*treq_out) return 1;
3506 
3507  return 0;
3508 }
3509 
3510 /** Pop a request off a connection's pending queue
3511  *
3512  * The request we return is advanced by the request moving out of the partial or
3513  * pending states, when the mux function signals us.
3514  *
3515  * If the same request is returned again and again, it means the muxer isn't actually
3516  * doing anything with the request we returned, and it's and error in the muxer code.
3517  *
3518  * One of these signalling functions must be used after the request has been popped:
3519  *
3520  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_complete
3521  * The request was completed. Either we got a synchronous response, or we knew the
3522  * response without contacting an external server (cache).
3523  *
3524  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_fail
3525  * Failed muxing the request due to a permanent issue, i.e. an invalid request.
3526  *
3527  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_partial
3528  * Wrote part of a request. This request will be returned on the next call to this
3529  * function so that the request_mux function can finish writing it. Only useful
3530  * for stream type connections. Datagram type connections cannot have partial
3531  * writes.
3532  *
3533  * - #fr_trunk_request_signal_sent Successfully sent a request.
3534  *
3535  * @param[out] treq_out to process
3536  * @param[in] tconn to pop a request from.
3537  * @return
3538  * - 1 if no more requests.
3539  * - 0 if a new request was written to treq_out.
3540  * - -1 if the connection was previously freed. Caller *MUST NOT* touch any
3541  * memory or requests associated with the connection.
3542  * - -2 if called outside of the muxer.
3543  */
3544 int fr_trunk_connection_pop_request(fr_trunk_request_t **treq_out, fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3545 {
3546  if (unlikely(tconn->pub.state == FR_TRUNK_CONN_HALTED)) return -1;
3547 
3548  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(IN_REQUEST_MUX(tconn->pub.trunk),
3549  "%s can only be called from within request_mux handler",
3550  __FUNCTION__)) return -2;
3551 
3552  *treq_out = tconn->partial ? tconn->partial : fr_heap_peek(tconn->pending);
3553  if (!*treq_out) return 1;
3554 
3555  return 0;
3556 }
3557 
3558 /** Signal that a trunk connection is writable
3559  *
3560  * Should be called from the 'write' I/O handler to signal that requests can be enqueued.
3561  *
3562  * @param[in] tconn to signal.
3563  */
3564 void fr_trunk_connection_signal_writable(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3565 {
3566  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3567 
3568  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!IN_HANDLER(tconn->pub.trunk),
3569  "%s cannot be called within a handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
3570 
3571  DEBUG3("[%" PRIu64 "] Signalled writable", tconn->pub.conn->id);
3572 
3573  trunk_connection_writable(tconn);
3574 }
3575 
3576 /** Signal that a trunk connection is readable
3577  *
3578  * Should be called from the 'read' I/O handler to signal that requests should be dequeued.
3579  *
3580  * @param[in] tconn to signal.
3581  */
3582 void fr_trunk_connection_signal_readable(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3583 {
3584  fr_trunk_t *trunk = tconn->pub.trunk;
3585 
3586  if (!fr_cond_assert_msg(!IN_HANDLER(tconn->pub.trunk),
3587  "%s cannot be called within a handler", __FUNCTION__)) return;
3588 
3589  DEBUG3("[%" PRIu64 "] Signalled readable", tconn->pub.conn->id);
3590 
3591  trunk_connection_readable(tconn);
3592 }

3594 /** Signal a trunk connection cannot accept more requests
3595  *
3596  * @param[in] tconn to signal.
3597  */
3598 void fr_trunk_connection_signal_inactive(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3599 {
3600  /* Can be called anywhere */
3601 
3602  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3603  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE:
3604  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
3605  trunk_connection_enter_inactive(tconn);
3606  break;
3607 
3608  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING:
3609  trunk_connection_enter_inactive_draining(tconn);
3610  break;
3611 
3612  default:
3613  return;
3614  }
3615 }
3616 
3617 /** Signal a trunk connection is no longer full
3618  *
3619  * @param[in] tconn to signal.
3620  */
3621 void fr_trunk_connection_signal_active(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn)
3622 {
3623  switch (tconn->pub.state) {
3624  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL:
3625  trunk_connection_auto_unfull(tconn); /* Mark as active if it should be active */
3626  break;
3627 
3628  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE:
3629  /*
3630  * Do the appropriate state transition based on
3631  * how many requests the trunk connection is
3632  * currently servicing.
3633  */
3634  if (trunk_connection_is_full(tconn)) {
3635  trunk_connection_enter_full(tconn);
3636  break;
3637  }
3638  trunk_connection_enter_active(tconn);
3639  break;
3640 
3641  /*
3642  * Unsetting the active flag just moves
3643  * the connection back to the normal
3644  * draining state.
3645  */
3646  case FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING: /* Only an external signal can trigger this transition */
3647  trunk_connection_enter_draining(tconn);
3648  break;
3649 
3650  default:
3651  return;
3652  }
3653 }
3654 
3655 /** Signal a trunk connection is no longer viable
3656  *
3657  * @param[in] tconn to signal.
3658  * @param[in] reason the connection is being reconnected.
3659  */
3660 void fr_trunk_connection_signal_reconnect(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn, fr_connection_reason_t reason)
3661 {
3662  fr_connection_signal_reconnect(tconn->pub.conn, reason);
3663 }

3665 /** Returns true if the trunk connection is in one of the specified states
3666  *
3667  * @param[in] tconn To check state for.
3668  * @param[in] state to check
3669  * @return
3670  * - True if trunk connection is in a particular state.
3671  * - False if trunk connection is not in a particular state.
3672  */
3673 bool fr_trunk_connection_in_state(fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn, int state)
3674 {
3675  return (bool)(tconn->pub.state & state);
3676 }
3677 
3678 /** Close connections in a particular connection list if they have no requests associated with them
3679  *
3680  * @param[in] trunk containing connections we want to close.
3681  * @param[in] head of list of connections to examine.
3682  */
3683 static void trunk_connection_close_if_empty(fr_trunk_t *trunk, fr_dlist_head_t *head)
3684 {
3685  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = NULL;
3686 
3687  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_next(head, tconn))) {
3688  fr_trunk_connection_t *prev;
3689 
3690  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) != 0) continue;
3691 
3692  prev = fr_dlist_prev(head, tconn);
3693 
3694  DEBUG3("Closing %s connection with no requests",
3695  fr_table_str_by_value(fr_trunk_connection_states, tconn->pub.state, "<INVALID>"));
3696  /*
3697  * Close the connection as gracefully
3698  * as possible by signalling it should
3699  * shutdown.
3700  *
3701  * The connection, should, if serviced
3702  * correctly by the underlying library,
3703  * automatically transition to halted after
3704  * all pending reads/writes are
3705  * complete at which point we'll be informed
3706  * and free our tconn wrapper.
3707  */
3708  fr_connection_signal_shutdown(tconn->pub.conn);
3709  tconn = prev;
3710  }
3711 }
3712 
3713 /** Rebalance connections across active trunk members when a new connection becomes active
3714  *
3715  * We don't have any visibility into the connection prioritisation algorithm
3716  * it's essentially a black box.
3717  *
3718  * We can however determine when the correct level of requests per connection
3719  * has been reached, by dequeuing and requeing requests up until the point
3720  * where the connection that just had a request dequeued, receives the same
3721  * request back.
3722  *
3723  * @param[in] trunk The trunk to rebalance.
3724  */
3725 static void trunk_rebalance(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
3726 {
3727  fr_trunk_connection_t *head;
3728 
3729  head = fr_heap_peek(trunk->active);
3730 
3731  /*
3732  * Only rebalance if the top and bottom of
3733  * the heap are not equal.
3734  */
3735  if (trunk->funcs.connection_prioritise(fr_heap_peek_tail(trunk->active), head) == 0) return;
3736 
3737  DEBUG3("Rebalancing requests");
3738 
3739  /*
3740  * Keep requeuing requests from the connection
3741  * at the bottom of the heap until the
3742  * connection at the top is shifted from that
3743  * position.
3744  */
3745  while ((fr_heap_peek(trunk->active) == head) &&
3746  trunk_connection_requests_requeue(fr_heap_peek_tail(trunk->active),
3747  FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_PENDING, 1, false));
3748 }
3749 
3750 /** Implements the algorithm we use to manage requests per connection levels
3751  *
3752  * This is executed periodically using a timer event, and opens/closes
3753  * connections.
3754  *
3755  * The aim is to try and keep the request per connection level in a sweet spot,
3756  * where there's enough outstanding work for the connection/pipelining to work
3757  * efficiently, but not so much so that we encounter increased latency.
3758  *
3759  * In the request enqueue and dequeue functions we record every time the
3760  * average number of requests per connection goes above the target count
3761  * and record every time the average number of requests per connection goes
3762  * below the target count.
3763  *
3764  * This may sound expensive, but in all cases we're just summing counters.
3765  * CPU time required does not increase with additional requests, only with
3766  * large numbers of connections.
3767  *
3768  * If we do encounter scaling issues, we can always maintain the counters
3769  * as aggregates as an optimisation later.
3770  *
3771  * If when the management function runs, the trunk was above the target
3772  * most recently, we:
3773  * - Return if we've been in this state for a shorter period than 'open_delay'.
3774  * - Return if we're at max.
3775  * - Return if opening a new connection will take us below the load target.
3776  * - Return if we last opened a connection within 'open_delay'.
3777  * - Otherwise we attempt to open a new connection.
3778  *
3779  * If the trunk we below the target most recently, we:
3780  * - Return if we've been in this state for a shorter period than 'close_delay'.
3781  * - Return if we're at min.
3782  * - Return if we have no connections.
3783  * - Close a connection if min is 0, and we have no outstanding
3784  * requests. Then return.
3785  * - Return if closing a new connection will take us above the load target.
3786  * - Return if we last closed a connection within 'closed_delay'.
3787  * - Otherwise we move a connection to draining state.
3788  */
3789 static void trunk_manage(fr_trunk_t *trunk, fr_time_t now)
3790 {
3791  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = NULL;
3792  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
3793  uint32_t average = 0;
3794  uint32_t req_count;
3795  uint16_t conn_count;
3796 
3797  DEBUG3("Managing trunk");
3798 
3799  /*
3800  * Cleanup requests in our request cache which
3801  * have been idle for too long.
3802  */
3803  while ((treq = fr_dlist_tail(&trunk->free_requests)) &&
3804  ((treq->last_freed + trunk->conf.req_cleanup_delay) <= now)) talloc_free(treq);
3805 
3806  /*
3807  * Free any connections which have drained
3808  * and we didn't reactivate during the last
3809  * round of management.
3810  */
3811  trunk_connection_close_if_empty(trunk, &trunk->inactive_draining);
3812  trunk_connection_close_if_empty(trunk, &trunk->draining);
3813  trunk_connection_close_if_empty(trunk, &trunk->draining_to_free);
3814 
3815  /*
3816  * Process deferred connection freeing
3817  */
3818  if (!trunk->in_handler) {
3819  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->to_free))) talloc_free(fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->to_free, tconn));
3820  }
3821 
3822  /*
3823  * A trunk can be signalled to not proactively
3824  * manage connections if a destination is known
3825  * to be unreachable, and doing so would result
3826  * in spurious connections still being opened.
3827  *
3828  * We still run other connection management
3829  * functions and just short circuit the function
3830  * here.
3831  */
3832  if (!trunk->managing_connections) return;
3833 
3834  /*
3835  * We're above the target requests per connection
3836  * spawn more connections!
3837  */
3838  if ((trunk->pub.last_above_target >= trunk->pub.last_below_target)) {
3839  /*
3840  * If connecting is provided, check we
3841  * wouldn't have too many connections in
3842  * the connecting state.
3843  *
3844  * This is a throttle in the case of transitory
3845  * load spikes, or a backend becoming
3846  * unavailable.
3847  */
3848  if ((trunk->conf.connecting > 0) &&
3849  (fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(trunk, FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING) >=
3850  trunk->conf.connecting)) {
3851  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - Too many (%u) connections in the connecting state",
3852  trunk->conf.connecting);
3853  return;
3854  }
3855 
3856  trunk_requests_per_connection(&conn_count, &req_count, trunk, now, true);
3857 
3858  /*
3859  * Only apply hysteresis if we have at least
3860  * one available connection.
3861  */
3862  if (conn_count && ((trunk->pub.last_above_target + trunk->conf.open_delay) > now)) {
3863  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - Need to be above target for %pVs. It's been %pVs",
3864  fr_box_time_delta(trunk->conf.open_delay),
3865  fr_box_time_delta(now - trunk->pub.last_above_target));
3866  return; /* too soon */
3867  }
3868 
3869  /*
3870  * We don't consider 'draining' connections
3871  * in the max calculation, as if we do
3872  * determine that we need to spawn a new
3873  * request, then we'd move all 'draining'
3874  * connections to active before spawning
3875  * any new connections.
3876  */
3877  if ((trunk->conf.max > 0) && (conn_count >= trunk->conf.max)) {
3878  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - Have %u connections, need %u or below",
3879  conn_count, trunk->conf.max);
3880  return;
3881  }
3882 
3883  /*
3884  * We consider requests pending on all connections
3885  * and the trunk's backlog as that's the current count
3886  * load.
3887  */
3888  if (!req_count) {
3889  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - No outstanding requests");
3890  return;
3891  }
3892 
3893  /*
3894  * Do the n+1 check, i.e. if we open one connection
3895  * will that take us below our target threshold.
3896  */
3897  if (conn_count > 0) {
3898  average = ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, (conn_count + 1));
3899  if (average < trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn) {
3900  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - Would leave us below our target requests "
3901  "per connection (now %u, after open %u)",
3902  ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, conn_count), average);
3903  return;
3904  }
3905  } else {
3906  (void)trunk_connection_spawn(trunk, now);
3907  return;
3908  }
3909 
3910  /*
3911  * If we've got a connection in the draining list
3912  * move it back into the active list if we've
3913  * been requested to add a connection back in.
3914  */
3915  tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->draining);
3916  if (tconn) {
3917  if (trunk_connection_is_full(tconn)) {
3918  trunk_connection_enter_full(tconn);
3919  } else {
3920  trunk_connection_enter_active(tconn);
3921  }
3922  return;
3923  }
3924 
3925  /*
3926  * Implement delay if there's no connections that
3927  * could be immediately re-activated.
3928  */
3929  if ((trunk->pub.last_open + trunk->conf.open_delay) > now) {
3930  DEBUG3("Not opening connection - Need to wait %pVs before opening another connection. "
3931  "It's been %pVs",
3932  fr_box_time_delta(trunk->conf.open_delay),
3933  fr_box_time_delta(now - trunk->pub.last_open));
3934  return;
3935  }
3936 
3937  DEBUG3("Opening connection - Above target requests per connection (now %u, target %u)",
3938  ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, conn_count), trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn);
3939  /* last_open set by trunk_connection_spawn */
3940  (void)trunk_connection_spawn(trunk, now);
3941  }
3942 
3943  /*
3944  * We're below the target requests per connection.
3945  * Free some connections...
3946  */
3947  else if (trunk->pub.last_below_target > trunk->pub.last_above_target) {
3948  if ((trunk->pub.last_below_target + trunk->conf.close_delay) > now) {
3949  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - Need to be below target for %pVs. It's been %pVs",
3950  fr_box_time_delta(trunk->conf.close_delay),
3951  fr_box_time_delta(now - trunk->pub.last_below_target));
3952  return; /* too soon */
3953  }
3954 
3955  trunk_requests_per_connection(&conn_count, &req_count, trunk, now, true);
3956 
3957  if (!conn_count) {
3958  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - No connections to close!");
3959  return;
3960  }
3961 
3962  if ((trunk->conf.min > 0) && ((conn_count - 1) < trunk->conf.min)) {
3963  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - Have %u connections, need %u or above",
3964  conn_count, trunk->conf.min);
3965  return;
3966  }
3967 
3968  if (!req_count) {
3969  DEBUG3("Closing connection - No outstanding requests");
3970  goto close;
3971  }
3972 
3973  /*
3974  * The minimum number of connections must be set
3975  * to zero for this to work.
3976  * min == 0, no requests, close all the connections.
3977  * This is useful for backup databases, when
3978  * maintaining the connection would lead to lots of
3979  * log file churn.
3980  */
3981  if (conn_count == 1) {
3982  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - Would leave connections "
3983  "and there are still %u outstanding requests", req_count);
3984  return;
3985  }
3986 
3987  /*
3988  * Do the n-1 check, i.e. if we close one connection
3989  * will that take us above our target threshold.
3990  */
3991  average = ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, (conn_count - 1));
3992  if (average > trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn) {
3993  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - Would leave us above our target requests per connection "
3994  "(now %u, after close %u)", ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, conn_count), average);
3995  return;
3996  }
3997 
3998  DEBUG3("Closing connection - Below target requests per connection (now %u, target %u)",
3999  ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, conn_count), trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn);
4000 
4001  close:
4002  if ((trunk->pub.last_closed + trunk->conf.close_delay) > now) {
4003  DEBUG3("Not closing connection - Need to wait %pVs before closing another connection. "
4004  "It's been %pVs",
4005  fr_box_time_delta(trunk->conf.close_delay),
4006  fr_box_time_delta(now - trunk->pub.last_closed));
4007  return;
4008  }
4009 
4010  /*
4011  * Inactive connections get counted in the
4012  * set of viable connections, but are likely
4013  * to be congested or dead, so we drain
4014  * (and possibly eventually free) those first.
4015  */
4016  if ((tconn = fr_dlist_tail(&trunk->inactive))) {
4017  /*
4018  * If the connection has no requests associated
4019  * with it then immediately free.
4020  */
4021  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0) {
4022  fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn); /* Also frees the tconn */
4023  } else {
4024  trunk_connection_enter_inactive_draining(tconn);
4025  }
4026  /*
4027  * It is possible to have too may connecting
4028  * connections when the connections are
4029  * taking a while to open and the number
4030  * of requests decreases.
4031  */
4032  } else if ((tconn = fr_dlist_tail(&trunk->connecting))) {
4033  fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn); /* Also frees the tconn */
4034 
4035  /*
4036  * Finally if there are no "connecting"
4037  * connections to close, and no "inactive"
4038  * connections, start draining "active"
4039  * connections.
4040  */
4041  } else if ((tconn = fr_heap_peek_tail(trunk->active))) {
4042  /*
4043  * If the connection has no requests associated
4044  * with it then immediately free.
4045  */
4046  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) == 0) {
4047  fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn); /* Also frees the tconn */
4048  } else {
4049  trunk_connection_enter_draining(tconn);
4050  }
4051  }
4052 
4053  trunk->pub.last_closed = now;
4054 
4055 
4056  return;
4057  }
4058 }
4059 
4060 /** Event to periodically call the connection management function
4061  *
4062  * @param[in] el this event belongs to.
4063  * @param[in] now current time.
4064  * @param[in] uctx The trunk.
4065  */
4066 static void _trunk_timer(fr_event_list_t *el, fr_time_t now, void *uctx)
4067 {
4068  fr_trunk_t *trunk = talloc_get_type_abort(uctx, fr_trunk_t);
4069 
4070  trunk_manage(trunk, now);
4071 
4072  if (trunk->conf.manage_interval > 0) {
4073  if (fr_event_timer_in(trunk, el, &trunk->manage_ev, trunk->conf.manage_interval,
4074  _trunk_timer, trunk) < 0) {
4075  PERROR("Failed inserting trunk management event");
4076  /* Not much we can do, hopefully the trunk will be freed soon */
4077  }
4078  }
4079 }
4080 
4081 /** Return a count of requests on a connection in a specific state
4082  *
4083  * @param[in] trunk to retrieve counts for.
4084  * @param[in] conn_state One or more connection states or'd together.
4085  * @param[in] req_state One or more request states or'd together.
4086  * @return The number of requests in a particular state, on connection in a particular state.
4087  */
4088 uint64_t fr_trunk_request_count_by_state(fr_trunk_t *trunk, int conn_state, int req_state)
4089 {
4090  uint64_t count = 0;
4091  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn = NULL;
4092  fr_heap_iter_t iter;
4093 
4094 #define COUNT_BY_STATE(_state, _list) \
4095 do { \
4096  if (conn_state & (_state)) { \
4097  tconn = NULL; \
4098  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_next(&trunk->_list, tconn))) { \
4099  count += fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, req_state); \
4100  } \
4101  } \
4102 } while (0);
4103 
4104  if (conn_state & FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) {
4105  for (tconn = fr_heap_iter_init(trunk->active, &iter);
4106  tconn;
4107  tconn = fr_heap_iter_next(trunk->active, &iter)) {
4108  count += fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(tconn, req_state);
4109  }
4110  }
4111 
4112  COUNT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL, full);
4113  COUNT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE, inactive);
4114  COUNT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING, inactive_draining);
4115  COUNT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING, draining);
4116  COUNT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE, draining_to_free);
4117 
4118  if (req_state & FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_BACKLOG) count += fr_heap_num_elements(trunk->backlog);
4119 
4120  return count;
4121 }
4122 
4123 /** Update timestamps for when we last had a transition from above target to below target or vice versa
4124  *
4125  * Should be called on every time a connection or request is allocated or freed.
4126  *
4127  * @param[out] conn_count_out How many connections we considered.
4128  * @param[out] req_count_out How many requests we considered.
4129  * @param[in] trunk to operate on.
4130  * @param[in] now The current time.
4131  * @param[in] verify if true (and this is a debug build), then assert if req_per_conn
4132  * has changed.
4133  * @return
4134  * - 0 if the average couldn't be calculated (no requests or no connections).
4135  * - The average number of requests per connection.
4136  */
4137 static uint64_t trunk_requests_per_connection(uint16_t *conn_count_out, uint32_t *req_count_out,
4138  fr_trunk_t *trunk, fr_time_t now,
4139  NDEBUG_UNUSED bool verify)
4140 {
4141  uint32_t req_count = 0;
4142  uint16_t conn_count = 0;
4143  uint64_t req_per_conn = 0;
4144 
4145  fr_assert(now > 0);
4146 
4147  /*
4148  * No need to update these as the trunk is being freed
4149  */
4150  if (trunk->freeing) goto done;
4151 
4152  /*
4153  * Count all connections except draining and draining to free.
4154  *
4155  * Omitting these connection states artificially raises the
4156  * request to connection ratio, so that we can preemptively spawn
4157  * new connections.
4158  *
4159  * In the case of FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING | FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING
4160  * the trunk management code has enough hysteresis to not
4161  * immediately reactivate the connection.
4162  *
4163  * In the case of TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE the trunk
4164  * management code should spawn a new connection to takes its place.
4165  *
4166  * Connections placed in the DRAINING_TO_FREE sate are being
4167  * closed preemptively to deal with bugs on the server we're
4168  * talking to, or misconfigured firewalls which are trashing
4169  * TCP/UDP connection states.
4170  */
4171  conn_count = fr_trunk_connection_count_by_state(trunk, FR_TRUNK_CONN_ALL ^
4172  (FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING |
4173  FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING |
4174  FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE));
4175 
4176  /*
4177  * Requests on all connections
4178  */
4179  req_count = fr_trunk_request_count_by_state(trunk,
4180  FR_TRUNK_CONN_ALL ^
4181  FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL);
4182 
4183  /*
4184  * No connections, but we do have requests
4185  */
4186  if (conn_count == 0) {
4187  if ((req_count > 0) && (trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn > 0)) goto above_target;
4188  goto done;
4189  }
4190 
4191  if (req_count == 0) {
4192  if (trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn > 0) goto below_target;
4193  goto done;
4194  }
4195 
4196  /*
4197  * Calculate the req_per_conn
4198  */
4199  req_per_conn = ROUND_UP_DIV(req_count, conn_count);
4200  if (req_per_conn > trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn) {
4201  above_target:
4202  /*
4203  * Edge - Below target to above target (too many requests per conn - spawn more)
4204  *
4205  * The equality check is correct here as both values start at 0.
4206  */
4207  if (trunk->pub.last_above_target <= trunk->pub.last_below_target) trunk->pub.last_above_target = now;
4208  } else if (req_per_conn < trunk->conf.target_req_per_conn) {
4209  below_target:
4210  /*
4211  * Edge - Above target to below target (too few requests per conn - close some)
4212  *
4213  * The equality check is correct here as both values start at 0.
4214  */
4215  if (trunk->pub.last_below_target <= trunk->pub.last_above_target) trunk->pub.last_below_target = now;
4216  }
4217 
4218 done:
4219  if (conn_count_out) *conn_count_out = conn_count;
4220  if (req_count_out) *req_count_out = req_count;
4221 
4222  /*
4223  * Check we haven't missed a call to trunk_requests_per_connection
4224  */
4225  fr_assert(!verify || (trunk->last_req_per_conn == 0) || (req_per_conn == trunk->last_req_per_conn));
4226 
4227  trunk->last_req_per_conn = req_per_conn;
4228 
4229  return req_per_conn;
4230 }
4231 
4232 /** Drain the backlog of as many requests as possible
4233  *
4234  * @param[in] trunk To drain backlog requests for.
4235  */
4236 static void trunk_backlog_drain(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4237 {
4238  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
4239 
4240  if (fr_heap_num_elements(trunk->backlog) == 0) return;
4241 
4242  /*
4243  * If it's always writable, this isn't
4244  * really a noteworthy event.
4245  */
4246  if (!trunk->conf.always_writable) DEBUG3("Draining backlog of requests");
4247 
4248  /*
4249  * Do *NOT* add an artificial limit
4250  * here. We rely on all available
4251  * connections entering the full
4252  * state and transitioning back to
4253  * active in order to drain the
4254  * backlog.
4255  */
4256  while ((treq = fr_heap_peek(trunk->backlog))) {
4257  switch (trunk_request_enqueue_existing(treq)) {
4258  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_OK:
4259  continue;
4260 
4261  /*
4262  * Signal to stop
4263  */
4264  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_IN_BACKLOG:
4265  break;
4266 
4267  /*
4268  * Failed enqueueing the request,
4269  * have it enter the failed state
4270  * which will free it and
4271  * re-enliven the yielded request.
4272  */
4273  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_DST_UNAVAILABLE:
4274  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_FAIL:
4275  trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
4276  continue;
4277 
4278  case FR_TRUNK_ENQUEUE_NO_CAPACITY:
4279  fr_assert(fr_heap_num_elements(trunk->active) == 0);
4280  return;
4281  }
4282  }
4283 }
4284 
4285 /** Force the trunk to re-establish its connections
4286  *
4287  * @param[in] trunk to signal.
4288  * @param[in] states One or more states or'd together.
4289  * @param[in] reason Why the connections are being signalled to reconnect.
4290  */
4291 void fr_trunk_reconnect(fr_trunk_t *trunk, int states, fr_connection_reason_t reason)
4292 {
4293 
4294 #define RECONNECT_BY_STATE(_state, _list) \
4295 do { \
4296  if (states & (_state)) { \
4297  size_t i; \
4298  for (i = fr_dlist_num_elements(&trunk->_list); i > 0; i--) { \
4299  fr_connection_signal_reconnect(((fr_trunk_connection_t *)fr_dlist_tail(&trunk->_list))->pub.conn, reason); \
4300  } \
4301  } \
4302 } while (0);
4303 
4304  /*
4305  * Connections in the 'connecting' state
4306  * may re-enter that state, so we need to
4307  * be careful not to enter an infinite
4308  * loop, as we iterate over the list
4309  * again and again.
4310  */
4311  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CONNECTING, connecting);
4312 
4313  if (states & FR_TRUNK_CONN_ACTIVE) {
4314  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn;
4315  while ((tconn = fr_heap_peek(trunk->active))) fr_connection_signal_reconnect(tconn->pub.conn, reason);
4316  }
4317 
4318  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INIT, init);
4319  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_FULL, full);
4320  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE, inactive);
4321  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_INACTIVE_DRAINING, inactive_draining);
4322  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_CLOSED, closed);
4323  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING, draining);
4324  RECONNECT_BY_STATE(FR_TRUNK_CONN_DRAINING_TO_FREE, draining_to_free);
4325 }

4327 /** Start the trunk running
4328  *
4329  */
4330 int fr_trunk_start(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4331 {
4332  uint16_t i;
4333 
4334  if (unlikely(trunk->started)) return 0;
4335 
4336  /*
4337  * Spawn the initial set of connections
4338  */
4339  for (i = 0; i < trunk->conf.start; i++) {
4340  DEBUG("[%i] Starting initial connection", i);
4341  if (trunk_connection_spawn(trunk, fr_time()) != 0) return -1;
4342  }
4343 
4344  if (trunk->conf.manage_interval > 0) {
4345  /*
4346  * Insert the event timer to manage
4347  * the interval between managing connections.
4348  */
4349  if (fr_event_timer_in(trunk, trunk->el, &trunk->manage_ev, trunk->conf.manage_interval,
4350  _trunk_timer, trunk) < 0) {
4351  PERROR("Failed inserting trunk management event");
4352  return -1;
4353  }
4354  }
4355  trunk->started = true;
4356  trunk->managing_connections = true;
4357 
4358  return 0;
4359 }

4361 /** Allow the trunk to open and close connections in response to load
4362  *
4363  */
4364 void fr_trunk_connection_manage_start(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4365 {
4366  if (!trunk->started || trunk->managing_connections) return;
4367 
4368  DEBUG3("Connection management enabled");
4369  trunk->managing_connections = true;
4370 }
4371 
4372 /** Stop the trunk from opening and closing connections in response to load
4373  *
4374  */
4375 void fr_trunk_connection_manage_stop(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4376 {
4377  if (!trunk->started || !trunk->managing_connections) return;
4378 
4379  DEBUG3("Connection management disabled");
4380  trunk->managing_connections = false;
4381 }

4383 /** Schedule a trunk management event for the next time the event loop is executed
4384  */
4385 int fr_trunk_connection_manage_schedule(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4386 {
4387  if (!trunk->started || !trunk->managing_connections) return 0;
4388 
4389  if (fr_event_timer_in(trunk, trunk->el, &trunk->manage_ev, 0, _trunk_timer, trunk) < 0) {
4390  PERROR("Failed inserting trunk management event");
4391  return -1;
4392  }
4393 
4394  return 0;
4395 }

4397 /** Order connections by queue depth
4398  *
4399  */
4400 static int8_t _trunk_connection_order_by_shortest_queue(void const *one, void const *two)
4401 {
4402  fr_trunk_connection_t const *a = talloc_get_type_abort_const(one, fr_trunk_connection_t);
4403  fr_trunk_connection_t const *b = talloc_get_type_abort_const(two, fr_trunk_connection_t);
4404 
4405  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(a, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) >
4406  fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(b, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL)) return +1;
4407  if (fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(a, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL) <
4408  fr_trunk_request_count_by_connection(b, FR_TRUNK_REQUEST_STATE_ALL)) return -1;
4409 
4410  return 0;
4411 }
4412 
4413 /** Free a trunk, gracefully closing all connections.
4414  *
4415  */
4416 static int _trunk_free(fr_trunk_t *trunk)
4417 {
4418  fr_trunk_connection_t *tconn;
4419  fr_trunk_request_t *treq;
4420 
4421  DEBUG4("Trunk free %p", trunk);
4422 
4423  trunk->freeing = true; /* Prevent re-enqueuing */
4424 
4425  /*
4426  * We really don't want this firing after
4427  * we've freed everything.
4428  */
4429  fr_event_timer_delete(&trunk->manage_ev);
4430 
4431  /*
4432  * Now free the connections in each of the lists.
4433  *
4434  * Each time a connection is freed it removes itself from the list
4435  * its in, which means the head should keep advancing automatically.
4436  */
4437  while ((tconn = fr_heap_peek(trunk->active))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4438  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->init))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4439  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->connecting))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4440  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->full))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4441  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->inactive))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4442  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->inactive_draining))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4443  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->closed))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4444  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->draining))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4445  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->draining_to_free))) fr_connection_signal_halt(tconn->pub.conn);
4446 
4447  /*
4448  * Process any deferred connection frees
4449  */
4450  while ((tconn = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->to_free))) talloc_free(fr_dlist_remove(&trunk->to_free, tconn));
4451 
4452  /*
4453  * Free any requests left in the backlog
4454  */
4455  while ((treq = fr_heap_peek(trunk->backlog))) trunk_request_enter_failed(treq);
4456 
4457  /*
4458  * Free any requests in our request cache
4459  */
4460  while ((treq = fr_dlist_head(&trunk->free_requests))) talloc_free(treq);
4461 
4462  return 0;
4463 }
4464 
4465 /** Allocate a new collection of connections
4466  *
4467  * This function should be called first to allocate a new trunk connection.
4468  *
4469  * After the trunk has been allocated, #fr_trunk_request_alloc and
4470  * #fr_trunk_request_enqueue should be used to allocate memory for trunk
4471  * requests, and pass a preq (protocol request) to the trunk for
4472  * processing.
4473  *
4474  * The trunk will then asynchronously process the request, writing the result
4475  * to a specified rctx. See #fr_trunk_request_enqueue for more details.
4476  *
4477  * @note Trunks may not be shared between multiple threads under any circumstances.
4478  *
4479  * @param[in] ctx To use for any memory allocations. Must be thread local.
4480  * @param[in] el to use for I/O and timer events.
4481  * @param[in] funcs Callback functions.
4482  * @param[in] conf Common user configurable parameters.
4483  * @param[in] log_prefix To prepend to global messages.
4484  * @param[in] uctx User data to pass to the alloc function.
4485  * @param[in] delay_start If true, then we will not spawn any connections
4486  * until the first request is enqueued.
4487  * @return
4488  * - New trunk handle on success.
4489  * - NULL on error.
4490  */
4491 fr_trunk_t *fr_trunk_alloc(TALLOC_CTX *ctx, fr_event_list_t *el,
4492  fr_trunk_io_funcs_t const *funcs, fr_trunk_conf_t const *conf,
4493  char const *log_prefix, void const *uctx, bool delay_start)
4494 {
4495  fr_trunk_t *trunk;
4496 
4497  /*
4498  * Check we have the functions we need
4499  */
4500  if (!fr_cond_assert(funcs->connection_alloc)) return NULL;
4501 
4502  MEM(trunk = talloc_zero(ctx, fr_trunk_t));
4503  trunk->el = el;
4504  trunk->log_prefix = talloc_strdup(trunk, log_prefix);
4505 
4506  memcpy(&trunk->funcs, funcs, sizeof(trunk->funcs));
4507  if (!trunk->funcs.connection_prioritise) {
4508  trunk->funcs.connection_prioritise = _trunk_connection_order_by_shortest_queue;
4509  }
4510  if (!trunk->funcs.request_prioritise) trunk->funcs.request_prioritise = fr_pointer_cmp;
4511 
4512  memcpy(&trunk->conf, conf, sizeof(trunk->conf));
4513 
4514  memcpy(&trunk->uctx, &uctx, sizeof(trunk->uctx));
4515  talloc_set_destructor(trunk, _trunk_free);
4516 
4517  /*
4518  * Unused request list...
4519  */
4520  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->free_requests, fr_trunk_request_t, entry);
4521 
4522  /*
4523  * Request backlog queue
4524  */
4525  MEM(trunk->backlog = fr_heap_talloc_alloc(trunk, _trunk_request_prioritise,
4526  fr_trunk_request_t, heap_id));
4527 
4528  /*
4529  * Connection queues and trees
4530  */
4531  MEM(trunk->active = fr_heap_talloc_alloc(trunk, trunk->funcs.connection_prioritise,
4532  fr_trunk_connection_t, heap_id));
4533  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->init, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4534  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->connecting, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4535  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->full, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4536  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->inactive, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4537  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->inactive_draining, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4538  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->closed, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4539  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->draining, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4540  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->draining_to_free, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4541  fr_dlist_talloc_init(&trunk->to_free, fr_trunk_connection_t, entry);
4542 
4543  DEBUG4("Trunk allocated %p", trunk);
4544 
4545  if (!delay_start) {
4546  if (fr_trunk_start(trunk) < 0) {
4547  talloc_free(trunk);
4548  return NULL;
4549  }
4550  }
4551 
4552  return trunk;
4553 }
